Last night in class, we discussed this week's assigned reading, "Getting Back into Place: Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World" by Edward S. Casey. The first chapter addresses “implacement” and the second, “displacement.” In the first chapter, Casey distinguishes that our contemporary culture centers around time as the situating force: we are running out of time, we have saved time, we are just in time. He argues that using place as the cultural center fosters a more grounded community. (This is a very rough summary, a disclaimer in case my professor or any other classmate reads this post.) So far, this book is the first reading that has captivated me.

GOP faces criticism as Jacksonville naturalization ceremonies are relocated following complaints that GOP activists registered new citizens as Republicans. By Gary Fineout and Alfonso Chardy, the citizenship ceremony in Jacksonville appeared to proceed as usual, with nearly 200 new Americans. Just before the new citizens left the June 29 event, an immigration official directing the swearing-in encouraged attendees to stop by a voter registration table—a common sight at naturalization ceremonies. However, this table was unusual: those distributing forms were Republican volunteers, and the party affiliation box had been pre-checked to make all new voters members of the GOP. It raised suspicions for Linda Cross, who was present to see her husband, Dario Cruz, take his citizenship oath.

The simplest approach I can suggest is to enter the sales at the citygate or storage facility and complete most of the pricing in a worksheet.

It puts the ball in the net or it gets the hose again. Absolutely amazing, I have nothing negative to say about this game as it has exceeded my expectations and will likely exceed yours too. Fluid movement, bug/crash-free, plenty of story/content to engage you, options for each day such as multiple practices, events (sponsorships), and even games. This review is purely based on playing mycareer, and so far, it's 10/10. Facescan worked really well for me (used it twice, although the first one gave me a peculiar forehead). Keep in mind, using the mynba2k17 app allows you to facescan for free and earn daily vc. #sellout

Magic fans beware... Wizards is reluctant to create a satisfactory digital game. Fundamentally, Magic: The Gathering is a social game. It's a game to enjoy with friends (or frenemies), laughing, talking smack, and delivering game-winning plays. Wizards of the Coast seems to have forgotten this. If you choose to play with friends, you can't earn gold, which is crucial. Gold is so essential that they have implemented a daily cap, understandable since gold unlocks everything in the game. However, prepare for a long and monotonous 1v1 grind against the computer or random opponents, whom you can't even communicate with. If you choose to play for free, it will take you roughly 4 hours a day for upwards of a month, by yourself, to unlock the cards.

Being the third installment in the trilogy, I'll address the negatives first. I quite dislike prequels as they technically move backwards in a story rather than forwards (an issue for every prequel). Granted, they offer more story-wise. The combat feels imprecise and doesn't capture the sharpness Arkham City managed to achieve. As of this recommendation (26/10/2013), there is a game-breaking bug that prevents a side mission from ever being completed (main story unaffected). Some gadgets have a ridiculous hotkey that requires your hand to travel across the keyboard to use. It might sound insignificant, but during combat, it could potentially disrupt your combo.

They significantly improved Shadow Warrior (2013). The boss fights are excellent, weapons feel impressive (perhaps not as great as those in Doom 2016, but still solid), and enemies aren't too tough if you're adept with elemental features and upgrades. The upgrade system is well-balanced, and once you get familiar with it, it isn't too tedious. The elemental features and limited ammo encourage varied weapon use. There are many cool, unique weapons that remain viable throughout most of the game. The music is fantastic, particularly the main theme and Stan Bush’s contributions.

So many things were done wrong. I don't even know how to start this review. This all refers to my career. My player is an outside scorer, PG, 1.71m, has maxed stats, and already obtained all necessary perks. Ok, now tell me, why does the shooting skill depend on a person's height? Why can a person who is 1.74m not become as good at shooting as someone who is 1.71m? I'm 1.87m in real life, made my first player with this height, and noticed I cannot reach a skill higher than 89. Why? That's pure discrimination! And why doesn’t the game tell me that before I create a character, or even when I reach the skill limit after weeks of playing?!?

I think this Assassin's Creed perfected the mechanics across all areas (ship battles, sailing, fishing, parkour, etc.). I felt much more connected to this character as well. The story begins quite rough but improves significantly as you play (I think this is true for every AC game personally). Edward was a very interesting character, as were all the side characters. I felt all the collectibles actually mattered in this AC game, unlike in previous ones. Perhaps it's because they seemed to have a bigger purpose. They definitely weren't required, but they were fun to collect, and you were rewarded in a very balanced way.

While I personally cannot recommend this game, it wasn't entirely terrible. The gunplay is decent, provided you have the funds to purchase gun parts, which is my main complaint: it's pay-to-win. If I could move past that, the game would be enjoyable, as the hardsuit is fun to use and HRV is an excellent idea. I'd choose this game over any Call of Duty title, but its pay-to-win microtransaction model is off-putting for me. If you are comfortable with this model, then by all means, enjoy it. But if you're like me and dislike pay-to-win games, just let this one go; it's not our cup of tea.

While not perfect, this game has been highly enjoyable. The save system and possibility of sudden death can lead to some frustration. I'm on my first playthrough and unfortunately lost my main character around hour 10 of 20ish. I would have really liked a save to reload at that point. I've since picked up a 3rd party mod/save tool to avoid catastrophic failures. Additionally, the aiming reticule is small and the zoom feels underpowered. Despite these issues, it's been a blast. I'm not typically a zombie fan, but the combination of strategy, missions, and first-person shooter/beat-'em-up elements is great. I've been playing it as often as I can get away... Just one more mission, just one more supply run—or I'm running away and want to get safe before shutting the game down.

An absolutely great strategy game! Having played every other wargame (European Escalation and ALB), I must say this one fits well. The number of units is impressive. Not sure exactly how many there are, but there's a ton! The graphics are beautiful, the sounds are great, and the gameplay is epic. The in-game chat box at the main menu is very entertaining, and I'm not kidding. However, if anyone thinks this game is 'easy', or if you are new to the strategy genre, it could take some time to master. Don't get upset; you will lose a lot of units. Just make sure you plan ahead and always have anti-air and anti-tank.

I was skeptical about this game before I played it. Wasn't even sure about purchasing it. I didn't know, the whole portal gun and portals concept seemed odd, even though I enjoy science fiction. How wrong I was. The jokes and voice acting in this game are phenomenal. Simply amazing. It's not cheesy (okay, it's sometimes cheesy). Each story character has their own sense of humor and distinct personality. And the level design? It's just fantastic. By the way, I never played the first Portal game. One of these days, I'm planning to if I can spare the time. I would never have considered it if I hadn't experienced the sequel.

Let's start with the pros (+) and cons (-) and then my thoughts on this game. +Some of the best characters +Good story +Loads of content +Customizable character (you can be male or female, whatever you like) +You can have a relationship with most of your companions (yes, fangirls, you can have a love interest) -Bad graphics (I don't think graphics really matter anyway) -Weird and awkward love scenes -Invisible walls -There's one mission that, in my opinion, was boring, but everyone has different tastes -+ This isn't really bad or good, but for those who care, your protagonist can't talk. Now for my thoughts. I love this game. This game is probably one of the best RPGs or games in general I have ever played. So, if you're an RPG fan, you probably already have this game.

"Yes, this is a nostalgic experience for those in their thirties who remember (at least in the UK) enduring the ever-annoying Timmy Mallett just for the five-minute Transformers cartoon. The voice actors for Optimus, Megatron, Bumblebee, and many others return, and are instantly recognizable. The distinctive cartoon transformation sound is present. Graphically, the cel-shaded presentation is flawless and very, very Generation One. Beyond that, it's actually an enjoyable game. The combat mechanics are exceptionally well executed. Transforming mid-fight is often essential and seamlessly integrated into combos, making it unlike High Moon's excellent War for/Fall of Cybertron games. Another difference is the strong emphasis on melee combat, though some enemies (e.g., Seekers) require switching to a ranged blaster.

I downloaded the game and played it for a while, and it was nothing special. I spent more time trying to log in than actually playing. There's a bug where it says there's an update to the terms of service and whenever you click 'accept' it just pops up again. You have to restart the client for it to work. That's not so bad, but why do I need to link my Steam and Gface accounts? They say it's for DLC, but why is that necessary? It's irreversible, so now I know that a company I don't care about has access to my Steam information. The game itself is so-so. It's easily recognizable as a COD clone, except somehow they made the gunplay worse... How is that even possible?

4k+ at 60fps (GTX 970), dual audio options, and includes Neptune gear. What's not to love? https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nygsb617tmo Excellent port and a great entry point if new to the series. Just keep in mind there is a lot of (skippable) talking. As usual, I suggest using a gamepad, but personally, I had no problems with a keyboard/mouse setup; both are completely rebindable. The price is about right, and I wouldn't have been unhappy with the purchase. More than half the DLC is included free, which is still plenty to play with. Recommended game for all JRPG/anime/visual novel fans, provided you don't mind long breaks between the action. Cheers. No-commentary playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=plslfvijaupszez9af395mvnk63xnhsj1_

I experienced no performance issues even at release, and after all these patches, it plays excellently. In my opinion, this is an excellent and fun game, although the format might be somewhat frustrating (where the free-roam city area repopulates with new enemies every time you progress the story). I particularly enjoyed the 'dual play' segments (where you can play Batman plus one more), and the ability to use the controller for most segments of the game. However, the mouse and keyboard use for the tank combat segments was greatly appreciated. Driving your Batmobile around the free-roam city, including when chasing the APC commanders, is ultimately enjoyable once you figure out how to use the brakes to skid around corners. Once you master that, driving around the city is really quite enjoyable!

An outstanding FPS shooter—that's the bottom line. It looks, sounds, and plays wonderfully with excellent FPS mechanics, an engaging story, compelling characters, flawless voice acting, and a powerful soundtrack. However, it's not for the faint-hearted; some cutscenes are quite intense and vivid. Yet, when a game is this impressive, its flaws become more noticeable, and here's what I found: - No SLI support, which was frustrating. I had to shelve the game until I upgraded my card, as it ran poorly on my old dual-GPU GTX 590. Ensure you have a decent single GPU card. - Irritatingly, small obstacles are often unclimbable.

English is not my native language. I am Dutch. Please overlook any typing or grammatical mistakes in my review of this fantastic game. I will break down this review into a few categories: - graphics - controls - sound - gameplay - replayability - graphics: the game is designed in a comic-like style. The graphics are very sleek with no unnecessary details and nice color schemes. It absolutely works for this game. The graphics can be set to 'high' without stressing your system. I run this game on an i5 Pentium processor, with NVIDIA GeForce 710M card - 8GB memory, and it runs smoothly (Windows 8.1). - controls: the game can be played with a keyboard, mouse, or an Xbox controller.

You can see by the hours I put into this game that I enjoy it. This is everything I wished a search game from COD would be. But don't buy this game thinking it's like COD, Battlefield, or any other shooter game. It's a game in its own class and should be treated as such. Can't tell you how many times I hear new players complain about getting killed really fast. Oh, God forbid you get shot in the face and die. It's not like that doesn't happen in real life or anything. Edit: Okay, so I've been playing this game for a while now. Thrown all kinds of money at it. One of the best MP games around. A good thing to play when you're not feeling CS:GO.

I'm two hours in and am thoroughly enjoying this game. It's incredibly funny. The gameplay is solid, the art design is stunning, the music is high quality and fitting, the story/world has captured my interest, and the puzzles are engaging. But the best aspect of this game is the comedy. If you've played any RPG since the dawn of video game RPGs, you'll appreciate the various jokes, parodies, and references; even if you’ve never played an RPG before, you’ll still find the humor enjoyable. If you played Final Fantasy VII or X, you absolutely need to try this game. Without giving too much away, I had to actually stop playing after two hours to give my cheeks a break from laughing and smiling so much. What a delight so far.

I'm really sorry. I try to be supportive of free-to-play games and indie developers, but I genuinely didn't enjoy this game. The description sounded perfect for me, but the execution didn't resonate. I love puzzle and exploration games, yet I found this one completely unintuitive. Even after researching how to progress, I just didn't find the gameplay fun. It also lacks a pause button, or if it has one, I never found it. Given that many sequences are timed, this seems like a critical oversight. I also feel this game is more cut scene than actual gameplay, leaving me drumming my fingers often.

This game... Phew, where to even start. It was absolutely beautiful; from story to graphics, I was hooked. The story wasn't just any story but actually felt like I was that person, trying to figure out what came next in the tale my character was telling. Gameplay was great, and I learned a lot about myself through this game (mainly my fear of heights, which I never had a problem with until the ice caverns). My gut churned the whole time, but I pushed through for Uncle Fred! If you guys made a DLC or second game, I would be the first to buy it and recommend it to everyone I know. Thanks to everyone involved in making this; you created an absolutely beautiful game.

Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth is a turn-based game where you build a civilization to achieve a specific goal or "victory." In previous games, you followed Earth's timeline through historical periods like the Stone Age, Medieval Age, and Modern Age. However, this game sets you in the future on a mission to colonize a new planet. What I enjoy is that 2K took a fresh approach and introduced new mechanics such as the Affinity System and Orbital Layer. However, these new mechanics can be overwhelming at times. What I think could be improved is incorporating additional artwork, such as the environment experienced when communicating with another leader.

Great game! Tons of replayability and an incredibly fun zombie survival game! Definitely in my top 5 zombie games. Edit: After playing 60+ hours, I can honestly say this is one of the better, more "realistic" zombie games. It's very much designed like a survival horror as you must conserve ammo, heal your wounds, take pills when infected, etc. Also, I find zombies to be well animated for a free-to-play game. P.S.: I would recommend playing with 1 or 2 friends, but the community is super friendly and you can usually make friends or chat with people in the chat or via voice comms.

02/07/2014 - It's unfortunate I can't fully recommend or enjoy this game. From the short time I've played it, I know I'd be hooked if it weren't for two major issues. No Aussie servers - one red bar puts you at a severe disadvantage and creates unbearable lag. Mind you, I played through the offline training mode, and it was stuttering and lagging as well (how does that even happen?). Couple that with the poor ping, and it just ruins the game experience. Everything glitches like crazy - the menus, backgrounds, training, and in-game. I've never had this happen before with this card and thought it might not like my OC. Set my GPU back to stock, and sure enough, it didn't help.

Very late last night, I finished this. The story isn't very deep or interesting, but what makes it stand out is the storytelling. The atmosphere is full to the brim, and the many collectibles do a great job of fleshing it out. I learned a lot about the world of Batman, so it was a little disappointing that so few bosses were in the game. Oh well, there are enough future games to rectify that. The combat is the right amount of challenge, though it's more on the easy side. Leveling up Batman wasn't very satisfying. It's the gadgets you upgrade and acquire during the campaign that add nice new gameplay mechanics. Accessing previously unreachable places offers a nice sense of progression.

'To the Moon' is no mere game; it is a veritable experience, and one of the best of my life. Think Telltale's "The Walking Dead" is sad? Well, it's no match for 'To the Moon'! Never before have I been so depressed yet fulfilled over something purely fictional. This masterpiece represents the pinnacle of storytelling, in my opinion, and the soundtrack is a gorgeously charming and perfect accompaniment. Yes, the controls are a bit finicky, and the gameplay is not the strong point, but the story is so fantastic that I did not care one bit. Plus, the humor of the game is great and does not intrude upon the distinguished nature of the story. And the Doctor Who references are endless.

Bastion is a brilliant game with a captivating storyline. Set after a calamity, you begin to rebuild on the bastion. The game offers plenty of choices, from what to build for advantages to choosing weapons and power-ups, as well as which drinks to use for bonus effects. The art style and music are fantastic—everything is vibrantly colorful at times, challenging the notion that the apocalypse must be dull. Best of all, the game features narration based on your actions; if you pick up a weapon and then swap it for another in the armory, the narration will comment on your decision to switch to the new weapon.

I first purchased this game during its early development, when the only currency was spacebux, and there was no 'tech tree.' This was when the game was truly enjoyable. All the guns at that time were equally overpowered, so there were no imbalance issues; everyone could defeat anyone at any moment. Additionally, the game used to provide you with unlimited gun slots and five loadouts. You'd expect that for a game boasting 'bajillions of guns,' they would at least offer more than six weapon slots and three loadouts before requiring payment for extras. At one point, I had about three pages of guns and was planning new ideas for more, because personally, that's where I found the fun.

This game was a surprising gem. One often encounters rave reviews of certain products that can be misleading. In this instance, however, the reviews accurately reflect the fun of this neat little game. It is an intriguing mix between a classic 2D platformer and a MOBA, and it does so with style. I found myself enjoying characters that I typically wouldn't in other MOBA games. Initially, I expected this preference to persist but decided to try a melee tank anyway. I was pleasantly surprised by the outcome and ended up exploring more as they were unlocked through playing. The art style and interface are oddly charming. Consequently, I now use one of the characters as my avatar and a wallpaper from creating a card set for the game.

I just started playing, but I love this game. I put on my headphones and lose myself in the game for hours at a time. It's been a while since a game has had that effect on me. The music sets the mood, the sound effects are spot on, and the controls are perfect. I look forward to every combat encounter, and they've optimized combat extremely well. I had my doubts about the naval combat system, but it is so much fun to lay waste to multiple fleets at a time! The only way to lose in this game is to fail to retreat. If the combat looks overwhelming, just get out of there, regroup, and counter-assault. Thanks, devs, for an amazing experience!

The reboot of the Devil May Cry franchise has introduced many changes to the series, especially for the protagonist, Dante. While fans of the original series might be upset by changes to their beloved character, it's undoubtedly for the better, and this new game by Ninja Theory proves it. DmC serves as the perfect entry point for newcomers to the series. It unveils the origins of an arrogant, cynical Dante and chronicles his journey from cynicism to selflessness. Throughout, the game weaves a clear narrative arc for the new Dante, making him a compelling character to watch. The story follows Dante as he's introduced to the corrupt world he once chose to ignore.

Where do I begin with this absolutely beautiful game? Its story is utterly charming. So much detail is invested in it, and it is a delightful mix of happiness, bad puns, annoying dogs, and secrets. It is serious when necessary but not a stranger to humorous moments. The character design is exceptional, with a variety of characters boasting distinct personalities and secrets. It stands out from other RPGs by allowing players not to kill anyone, an uncommon concept in RPGs. With abundant inspiration from EarthBound, one of the finest RPGs I have encountered, you know it will be exceptional. It effortlessly boasts the best soundtrack I've heard in ages.

I recommend this solely because it's free and might offer a more enjoyable experience for others. As for my experience, the game didn't impact me. Half the story relies on shock value. I wasn't shocked or emotionally moved in any way. Perhaps I'm desensitized, or it was too simple to evoke a reaction. The other half of the game attempts to portray (literally) a person in mental decline, dealing with obsession, hallucination, depression, and other issues. In theory, it's a cool concept. However, the game took me just 10 minutes to finish, and that's with reading and absorbing every bit of information I could.

Do I even need to explain why Portal is amazing? Portal is a puzzle game that introduces a concept and then lets you engage. It's an amazing way to test your mind while still being fun. Although this game isn't as story-heavy, it did give birth to one of the most popular games of 2011. I still play this game and beat it when I am feeling bored and love to see what gave birth to a legend. Gameplay: Portal's gameplay is quite simple to explain, at least. You use portals to your advantage, along with buttons that activate parts of the puzzle. Two buttons are in the game: one that you press and one that requires a cube.

If you can overlook the bugs (I personally experienced only two: one minor and the other quite annoying) edit: both bugs are resolved. One fix increased my FPS from 60-90 to 80-120. If you are looking for a space exploration game, I can definitely recommend this. Since most reviews are about specs, I'll include mine: i5 6600k (~200€), Radeon RX480 (~200€), Z170 Pro-Gaming (~150€), 16GB DDR4 RAM (~70€). ~650€ is within the medium price range, though, granted, this rig is quite new. Almost constant 60+ FPS on high settings with V-Sync enabled. I genuinely can't believe 90% of the comments claiming they're using an overkill setup and getting 20 FPS.

Remember Age of Mythology? Yes, it's been that long since there's been an RTS game of such quality. Divinity: Dragon Commander comes very close to these borders of my personal favorite RTS game. Combine this with a significant Risk-like grand strategy mode and there, it hits the spot. I try not to be overly biased due to the fact that this game allows you to turn into a dragon, aiding your troops by supporting, attacking, and even commanding unit production, direction, and spawning simultaneously. Honestly, I do like the complex RTS games nowadays. Think of Civilization V and so on. However, such games attempt to cram intricate mechanics, charts, and resources all into one complex game mode.

Undertale combines its elements to create something greater than the sum of its parts. The graphics are excellent for a retro title and the music is superb; together, they form truly beautiful and impactful moments. The script ranges from comedic to dramatic, heartbreaking to hopeful, sometimes all at once, all while turning RPG tropes on their head. And all of this without even touching on the world, characters, story, or gameplay... I could write entire pages about it. But instead, I'll just say this: if you like RPGs, play this game. If you like video games, play this game. If you have seven free hours before your death, play this game.

I've only had this game for a few months, and in that brief time, two DLCs have been released, along with patches that have transformed an already great game into an excellent one. The developers are very active within the community, and it shows in the various discussion forums and dev diaries. There is a fairly steep learning curve to the game's mechanics, which I am still trying to master; however, this breadth of strategy allows you numerous ways to achieve goals and exploit certain situations. The game, in my opinion, is nearly infinitely replayable. I find myself captivated in every session I play, regardless of how the playthrough is progressing.

Warframe is an engaging game for the first few hours. After these enjoyable hours, you'll notice that what's left is repetition in its combat, enemies, and gameplay. The major highlight is that the developers work hard and provide semi-frequent updates that generally include plenty of content, from sweeping changes to some of the game’s systems, new warframes, and other tweaks/features. It's a good game to play casually. Though I doubt it will hold your attention beyond a few months unless you really enjoy grinding. The upside is that the game is free, so I'd recommend giving it a try. If you're looking for a quick fix, try it out.

This game is so incredibly boring. I bought it because I believed it was a PC version of "Katamari Damacy," a popular and delightful PS2 game. Sadly, it's far from it. In this game, you go around absorbing increasingly larger objects to grow bigger and absorb even more. However, the gameplay isn't as smooth as it could be, the levels lack creativity, and what exists is a surreal horror show. I don't mean an entertaining horror show, but one that makes you feel rather depressed and reconsider whether life is all it should be. Every "living" creature in this game, from small pets to human beings, makes me wonder if the creators had an interest in taxidermy.

Alright. Let me explain a few things. As someone very interested in politics, I was eager to try this game when I first heard about it. I thought, 'Oh wow! A simulator of the road to becoming president! That sounds fun!' Well, it wasn't. The game starts by asking you to pick a side: Republican or Democrat. There's no independent or third party. Slightly disappointed, but still optimistic, I continued to see what I could do. I'll give the game credit; the character customization, although limited, is pretty fun to explore. It's the only time you can choose whether to wear your head or not in a campaign. Literally.

Fallout 3's story was superior. Settlements interfere with the narrative to the point that you'll find yourself resenting babysitting them instead of advancing the plot. Some keys are hardcoded and cannot be rebound. Bugs abound. My pipboy vanished permanently at one point, and I had to research console commands to retrieve it. You don't even have to earn power armor—it's basically handed to you from the start, and power cores are abundant in trader shops. The value of power armor has significantly decreased from previous Fallout games. The story is mediocre; everything about this game is average, except it doesn't crash every 10 minutes like Fallout 3. It's very stable compared to Fallout 3. Is it better than Fallout 3? No. Is it better than New Vegas? No. This title was immensely overhyped for how disappointing it actually is.

My stats (at the time of writing this review): - 8.6 hours to reach the end - 10 collectibles found out of 25 - zero achievements out of 15 What I liked: - Visuals up until the last level (ice caves) are impressive - The story isn't great, but the ending (after the closing credits) somewhat redeemed the time spent playing. What I disliked: - Visuals in the final level are uninteresting - The gameplay in the last level becomes significantly harder, resulting in a frustrating experience of repeating actions until successful - Achievements are too challenging. There are 13 (out of 15) achievements that fewer than 2.1% of players have earned!

Pros: +graphic Cons: -bugs (especially with the environment, you may get stuck or your shots may hit an invisible wall despite having a clear line of sight) -game is handholding/babysitting -dumb AI -enemies always seem to know where you are once spotted -godlike accuracy by enemies, which is frustrating like the first ghost warrior -terrible checkpoints and saves -boring story that I couldn't care less about. I will not recommend it unless it's 90% off; even then I find playing this game an extremely boring chore, just playing to finish it and move to the next game in my library. Considering the time wasted on the first ghost warrior (which was equally boring, and I felt liberated when I finished it), I probably won't play it to the end.

Review for 29/11/2015: Do not buy this game; servers are offline. You can't play. No compres este juego; servidores offline. No puedes jugar. While I could play it, I enjoyed it. As the Steve Miller Band song goes: "Go on, take the money and run!" https://youtu.be/-wcfugcollu?t=54 — English. I spent 73 minutes playing the game. OMG, just an hour into this game! It's awesome! Some guns are overpowered, and matchmaking is sometimes unfair, but hey, BF3 is worse. Matchmaking paired newbies with high-level players who weren't even real humans; you'd shoot them in the face, and nothing would happen!

I understand why others enjoy this game, but it wasn't for me. I have a Vive, and I prefer room-sized games with controllers. While the game's universe is initially awe-inspiring, I found its scale hindered my enjoyment. The learning curve and the time needed to accomplish something interesting at the start were too steep for me. If I were more patient and had more time for gaming, it might have been compelling. However, I lack both, and there are many other VR games I'd rather play.

Undoubtedly my favorite first-person shooter of all time. Run-and-gun enthusiasts need not apply. Recoil and ballistics are realistic. Single hits to the chest, neck, or head from rifle-caliber weapons usually result in death unless they just graze you. Rounds drop over distance, and short, controlled bursts are required if you wish to remain on target. There is no magical ammunition pool. If you reload halfway through your magazine frequently, you will have a pouch full of partially full mags. You can't run forever. If you sprint for a while, your aim will suffer as you gasp heavily until you catch your breath. Rest your weapon on your elbows while prone or on a windowsill to steady your aim. Accuracy suffers when standing.

Let me start by saying I did not purchase EU when it first came out; I got it on sale, which included EW, so I never experienced the issues some people claim to have had. I loved that game, though it was unforgiving in the early stages but rewarding when you did things right. As for XCOM 2, I love it; the game plays well for me on medium, and I am running a GTX 560 with 2GB of VRAM. Initially, the game set itself to high, and it was a bit sluggish, though not to the point of being unplayable. However, when I dropped it to medium, it smoothed out. I'm not sure if I'm just lucky when it comes to having issues with games, but it seems that most of the negative reviews sound like they are coming from some really entitled people.

+rpg leveling +wide variety of ship types +physics-based movement for both ships and projectiles/missiles +easy-to-learn resource management +dark humor -grind-intensive (if underutilizing the civvy station types) -subpar AI teammates -low variety of equipment types -low variety of leveling skills (that is, no branching) Listen, this game is fun as hell. Despite my minuses above, there is still some variety and strategy to be had. It starts off fast and really picks up. Even though there's a low variety of equipment, it still feels like there's always another ship to unlock or skill to level up. The best way to increase the life of this game is the mods. Fight for Universe is easily the star, but Big Fight for Beef is also very good.

Global leaders converge to navigate uncertainty as over 2,000 business and political figures from across the world arrive in the Swiss mountain town of Davos for the annual World Economic Forum (WEF). Over five days, they will address issues ranging from China's economic influence to Iraq's future following this Sunday's elections. UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki are among the over 20 government leaders and heads of state attending the gathering. Unlike previous years, protests against the WEF are expected to be less intense. Anti-globalization campaigners have canceled a demonstration planned for the weekend. The Brazilian city of Porto Alegre will host the alternative World Social Forum, scheduled to coincide with the WEF's more opulent event in Davos.

The deadline for the Fiat-GM deal approaches, with Fiat and General Motors (GM) needing to resolve a disagreement over a potential takeover by midnight on 1 February. At this deadline, Fiat gains the right to sell its car division to GM, as part of an alliance agreed upon in 2000. However, GM, whose European operations are losing money, no longer wants the unprofitable Fiat unit. Reports of stalled talks led Fiat shares to fall 1.2% on Tuesday, following a 4% gain on Monday fueled by hopes of a payoff. The U.S. firm is reportedly offering about $2bn (£1.06bn) to exit the arrangement. GM contends the deal was voided by Fiat's decision to sell its finance arm and halve GM's stake via a capital-raising effort. The 2000 alliance was formed during a race between GM and DaimlerChrysler to partner with Fiat.

Cardinal criticizes Iraq war cost: billions of pounds spent on conflict in Iraq and the Middle East should have been used to reduce poverty, Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O’Connor has said. The head of the Catholic Church in England and Wales made the comments on BBC Radio 4 and will reiterate his stance in his Christmas midnight mass. The cardinal used a Christmas message to denounce the war in Iraq as a "terrible" waste of money. He and the Archbishop of Canterbury have both spoken out about the war. Speaking on BBC Radio 4's Thought for the Day slot, he criticized the fact that "billions" have been spent on war, instead of being used to lift people "out of dire poverty and malnourishment and disease." The cardinal said 2005 should be the year for campaigning to "make poverty history.

British hopes of winning major Oscars were dashed as UK stars failed to secure acting and directing awards. Despite three nominations, Mike Leigh's "Vera Drake" did not win the director or screenplay prizes, and there was no award for star Imelda Staunton. Kate Winslet lost the Best Actress category to Hilary Swank, while Clive Owen and Sophie Okonedo also missed out on Best Supporting roles. However, the UK's Andrea Arnold won the Short Film Award for her gritty drama "Wasp." Arnold, who hosted children's television shows "Number 73" and "Motormouth" in the 1980s, described the win as "totally overwhelming." "Wasp" tells the story of a single mother living on the breadline, outpacing films by fellow UK nominees Gary McKendry and Ashvin Kumar.

Halloween writer Debra Hill dies. Screenwriter and producer Debra Hill, renowned for her work on the '70s horror classic Halloween, has died in Los Angeles at the age of 54. Hill, who had been battling cancer, co-wrote the 1978 film featuring Jamie Lee Curtis as a babysitter terrorized by a psychopath. Directed by John Carpenter, it grossed over $60 million (£31.3 million) worldwide—a record for independent films at that time. Hill also collaborated with Carpenter on Escape from New York and The Fog. Born in New Jersey, Hill began her career as a production assistant and advanced through the ranks, becoming an assistant director and second-unit director before her collaboration with Carpenter. She was widely regarded as a pioneering woman in film, taking on roles in the '70s traditionally held by men.

Broadband fuels online expression—fast web access is encouraging more people to express themselves online, research suggests. A quarter of broadband users in Britain regularly upload content and have personal sites, according to a report by UK think-tank Demos. It said that having an always-on, fast connection is changing the way people use the internet. More than five million households in the UK have broadband, and that number is growing fast. The Demos report looked at the impact of broadband on people’s net habits. It found that more than half of those with broadband logged on to the web before breakfast. One in five even admitted to getting up in the middle of the night to browse the web. More significantly, argues the report, broadband is encouraging people to take a more active role online.

Yukos is returning to U.S. courts. The Russian oil and gas company is scheduled for a U.S. court appearance on Thursday as it continues to fight for survival. The firm is currently being dismantled by Russian authorities to settle a $27bn (£14bn) tax bill. Yukos filed for bankruptcy in the U.S., attempting to leverage international business law to halt the forced sale of its major oil production unit, Yuganskneftegas. The unit was sold for $9.4bn to the state oil firm Rosneft, but this occurred only after the state auction was disrupted. Yukos lawyers now contend that the auction violated U.S. bankruptcy law. The company and its main shareholders have vowed to pursue any buyer of its assets, using all available legal means.

Voters flock to blog awards site as voting is underway for the annual Bloggies, which recognize the best weblogs—online spaces where people publish their thoughts—of the year. Nominations were announced on Sunday, but traffic to the official site was so heavy that it was temporarily closed due to too many visitors. Weblogs have been nominated in 30 categories, from the top regional blog to the best-kept-secret blog. Blogs had a significant year, with a top U.S. dictionary naming "blog" the word of 2004. Technorati, a blog search engine, tracks about six million blogs and states that more than 12,000 are added daily. A blog is created every 5.8 seconds, according to U.S. research think tank Pew Internet and American Life, but less than 40% of these are updated at least once every two months.

Chinese dam firm 'defies Beijing': The China Three Gorges Project Corp is refusing to comply with a government order to halt construction on one of its massive dams, the Chinese state press reported. The builder of the Three Gorges Dam is continuing work on the sister Xiluodu Dam, stated the Beijing News. The Xiluodu Dam is among 30 large-scale projects paused due to inadequate environmental checks. The Beijing News mentioned that the company might opt to pay a fine instead. The firm has also disregarded orders to cease construction at two other projects - the Three Gorges underground power plant and the Three Gorges Project electrical power supply plant. To date, only 22 out of the 30 construction projects targeted by China's State Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) for not conducting mandatory environmental impact assessments have complied with the shutdown order.

Manchester United reduced Chelsea's Premiership lead to nine points after a scrappy victory over Manchester City, winning 2-0. Wayne Rooney connected with Gary Neville's cross to the near post with a low shot, which deflected off Richard Dunne to put United ahead. Seven minutes later, the unfortunate Dunne hooked a volley over David James' head and into his own net. Steve McManaman squandered City's best chance when he shot wide from three yards in the first half. In the opening 45 minutes, United seemed unlikely to achieve the win they needed to maintain any chance of catching Chelsea in the title race. Their approach was more labored than patient, and they managed to create just one chance—a Paul Scholes header over the bar.

Wales 'must learn health lessons,' says the new health minister, who believes there are insights to gain from England in addressing waiting lists. Dr. Brian Gibbons, on his first full day in the role after Jane Hutt was dismissed, acknowledged "big challenges" but insisted the "essentials" were in place. However, both Plaid Cymru and the Liberal Democrats said Dr. Gibbons needed to change policy. Meanwhile, Ms. Hutt defended her record, stating that waiting times and lists were "only 10% of the health agenda." Dr. Gibbons, a former GP in Blaengwynfi, in the Upper Afan Valley, before becoming AM for Aberavon, mentioned that NHS staff desired a period of consolidation after "tremendous change and reform." One of the most significant issues faced by Ms. Hutt during her five-and-a-half years as the assembly's first health minister was the length of waiting lists in Wales.

Ferguson hails Man Utd's resolve. Manchester United's Alex Ferguson praised his players' gutsy performance in the 1-0 win at Aston Villa. "That was our hardest away game of the season, and it was a fantastic game of football, end-to-end with lots of excellent passing," said the Old Trafford boss. "We showed lots of character and guts and we weren't going to lose. I look at that fixture and think we've been there and won, while Arsenal and Chelsea have yet to come, and Villa may have some players back when they do." Ferguson also praised senior stars Ryan Giggs and Roy Keane, who came off the bench for the injured John O'Shea. "Roy came on and brought a bit of composure to the midfield which we needed and which no other player has.

A documentary offering a candid look at the life of chart-topping singer George Michael will be shown at this year's Berlin Film Festival. Titled 'A Different Story,' it will screen in the Panorama section of the festival, which runs from 10-20 February. The film features the singer discussing both his career and personal life, from his Wham! days to more recent events. Michael will attend the festival to introduce the screening on 16 February. Director Southan Morris and executive producer Andy Stephens will also be present. The 93-minute film showcases Michael discussing his early Wham! days, his later career, his legal battles with record label Sony, and his opposition to the Iraq War and American politics.

Downloads now enter the US singles chart as digital music downloads are included in the main US singles chart for the first time. Billboard's Hot 100 chart now incorporates data from sales of music downloads, which were previously part of a separate download chart. Green Day's "Boulevard of Broken Dreams" is currently number two on Billboard's pop chart and tops its digital chart. Download sales are set to be included in the UK singles chart later this year. Digital sales in the US are already used to compile Billboard's Hot Digital Sales chart. They will now be combined with sales of physical singles and airplay data to create the new Hot 100 chart. Its second new chart, the Pop 100, also combines airplay, digital, and physical sales but limits its airplay information to US radio stations that play chart music.

Anti-spam laws hit a spammer hard as the internet's self-declared "spam king" seeks bankruptcy protection. Scott Richter, the man behind OptInRealBig.com and billions of junk mail messages, stated that lawsuits had forced the company into Chapter 11. OptInRealBig faced several legal battles, most notably against Microsoft, which is pursuing millions of dollars in damages. The company said filing for Chapter 11 would help it resolve its legal issues while continuing to operate. Listed as the third biggest spammer globally by junk mail watchdog Spamhaus, OptInRealBig was sued in December 2003 for sending mail messages that violated anti-spam laws. The lawsuit was initiated by Microsoft and New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, who alleged that Mr. Richter and his accomplices sent billions of spam messages through 514 compromised addresses in 35 countries.

Arnesen denies rift with Santini. Tottenham sporting director Frank Arnesen has denied that coach Jacques Santini resigned due to a clash of personalities at White Hart Lane. There had been newspaper speculation that Santini felt undermined by Arnesen's role at the club. "It is absolutely not true," Arnesen told BBC Radio Five Live. "There is only one thing that made him resign, and that is his own personal problems. He has talked to me recently and said this matter is absolutely for himself." Arnesen said he was unable to shed light on the problems that caused Santini to quit after just 13 games in charge. He added: "Jacques has never gone into exactly what it was. But I trust him in that; you have to accept it. I think we should respect it.

Ireland surged past Scotland, maintaining their Six Nations Grand Slam ambitions with an impressive victory at Murrayfield. Hugo Southwell's try gave the Scots an early 8-0 lead, but scores from locks Malcolm O'Kelly and Paul O'Connell put the visitors in command by half-time. A third try from wing Denis Hickie and a third penalty from Ronan O'Gara, who kicked 13 points, extended the lead. Jon Petrie scored a second try for Scotland, but late scores from John Hayes and Gavin Duffy sealed victory. After two hard-earned away victories, Eddie O'Sullivan's side can now look forward to welcoming England to Lansdowne Road in a fortnight. Scotland will try to give their coach Matt Williams a first Six Nations victory when Italy come to Edinburgh, but they again struggled to convert pressure into points.

The economy will be the focus of the election battle, with Britain's economic future central to Labour's campaign, Chancellor Gordon Brown has said. He spoke after cabinet members held their final meeting at No. 10 before the expected election announcement. He stated voters would recognize that Labour had brought stability and growth and would continue to do so. Meanwhile, the Tories outlined their plans to tackle "yob culture," and the Lib Dems offered more details about their proposals to replace council tax. Earlier, the Archbishop of Canterbury wrote to all three parties, urging them not to exploit people's fears during the election. In an open letter, he implored them not to turn the election into a competition over who can stir greatest fear about terrorism, asylum, and crime.

Brizzel to run AAA's in Sheffield Ballymena sprinter Paul Brizzel will be among eight of Ireland's European indoor hopefuls competing in this weekend's AAA's Championships. US-based Alistair Cragg and Mark Carroll are the only Irish athletes selected so far for the Europeans who will not run in Sheffield. Brizzel will defend his 200m title in the British trials. In-form James McIlroy will hope to confirm his place in the British team for Madrid by winning the 800m title. McIlroy has been in tremendous form on the European circuit in recent weeks. He is one of the fastest 800m runners in the world this winter and already seems assured of a place in Madrid. Corkman Mark Carroll confirmed midweek that he would join Cragg in the European Championships. Carroll is ranked number three in the world 3000m ranking at the moment with Cragg occupying the top spot.

Robinson aims for dual-code success: England rugby union captain Jason Robinson has set his sights on success over Australia on Saturday. Robinson, a former rugby league international who switched codes in 2000, leads England against Australia at Twickenham at 1430 GMT. At 1815 GMT, Great Britain's rugby league team faces Australia in the final of the Tri-Nations tournament. "Beating the Aussies in both games would be a massive achievement, especially for league," said Robinson. England has the opportunity to secure their third autumn international victory after wins over Canada and South Africa, and to avenge June's 51-15 loss to the Wallabies. Meanwhile, Great Britain could end 34 years of failure against Australia with victory at Elland Road.

Warning over tsunami aid website: internet users are being advised to avoid a scam website claiming to collect donations for tsunami victims. The site appears legitimate because it uses an older version of the official Disasters Emergency Committee webpage. However, the DEC has no association with the fraudulent site and states it has reported this to the police. This site is just the latest among many scams attempting to exploit the goodwill generated by the tsunami disaster. The link to the website is included in a spam email currently circulating. The message's subject line reads "Urgent Tsunami Earthquake Appeal," and its text exhibits the poor grammar and bad spelling typical of many other phishing attempts.

Iraq to invite phone licence bids. Iraq is set to invite bids for two telephone licenses, aiming to significantly boost nationwide coverage over the next decade. Bids are sought from local, Arab, and foreign companies, Iraq's Ministry of Communications announced. The winner will partner with the Iraqi Telecommunications and Post Company (ITPC). The firms will install and operate a fixed phone network, providing voice, fax, and internet services. The ministry aims to increase Iraq's "very low telephone service penetration rate from about 4.5% today to about 25% within 10 years." It also hopes to develop a "highly visible and dynamic telecommunications sector." Details of the bidding and tender process will be published on the ministry's website on February 9. It also plans a roadshow for investors in Amman, Jordan.

More women turn to internet security. Older people and women are increasingly taking charge of protecting home computers against malicious online attacks, according to a two-year study. The number of women purchasing programs to protect PCs from viruses, spam, and spyware rose by 11.2% each year between 2002 and 2004. The study, conducted for the internet security firm Preventon, shows that security messages are reaching a diverse audience. It is estimated that 40% of those buying home internet security programs are retired. Over the last three years, that number has increased by an average of 13.2%. Notably, more retired women (53%) are buying security software than retired men. The research reflects the changing stereotypes and demographics of web users, as well as growing awareness of the greater risks that high-speed broadband connections can pose to surfers.

Podcasts mark the rise of DIY radio. An Apple iPod or other digital music player can hold up to 10,000 songs, which is a vast amount of space to fill. More and more iPod owners are filling that space with audio content created by a surprising assortment of producers. This trend is called "podcasting," and its strongest advocate is former MTV host and VJ (video jockey) Adam Curry. Podcasting derives its name from the Apple iPod, although you don't need an iPod to create or listen to a podcast. A podcast is essentially an internet-based radio show that podcasters create, often in the comfort of their own home. They need only a microphone, a PC, and some editing software. They then upload their shows to the internet, allowing others to download and listen to them, all for free.

Andrea Levy, winner of the Orange Prize, has seen her book "Small Island" win the Whitbread Novel of the Year Award. She is now the favorite to win the overall prize after beating Booker winner Alan Hollinghurst's "The Line of Beauty." Geraldine McCaughrean has picked up the children's fiction award for the third time for "Not the End of the World." All category winners will compete for the Whitbread Book of the Year title, which carries a £25,000 prize. A panel of judges, including Sir Trevor McDonald, actor Hugh Grant, and writer Joanne Harris, will meet on 25 January to decide the overall winner, with the announcement being made later that evening. Bookmaker William Hill has placed London-based Levy's novel as the 6/4 favorite to win.

Yukos seeks court action on sale. Yukos will return to a U.S. court on Wednesday to seek sanctions against Baikal Finance Group, the little-known firm that has bought its main asset. Yukos has stated it will sue Baikal and others involved in the sale of Yuganskneftegas for $20 billion in damages. Yukos' U.S. lawyers will attempt to have Baikal assets frozen after the Russian government ignored a U.S. court order last week blocking the sale. Baikal’s background and its motives for buying the unit remain unclear. Russian newspapers have claimed that Baikal—which bought the Yuganskneftegas production unit for $9.4 billion (261 billion roubles, £4.8bn) at a state-provoked auction—has strong links with Surgutneftegas, Russia's fourth-biggest oil producer.

Hearts 2-1 Livingston: Hearts secured their Scottish Cup quarter-final victory against Livingston with two goals in the first 10 minutes. Lee Miller scored within the opening 60 seconds, heading over Colin Meldrum and into the net from a Jamie McAllister free kick. McAllister himself scored the second by meeting Saulius Mikoliunas' cross at the back post, putting the game beyond the visitors. Craig Easton headed in a controversial goal after an hour, but Hearts held firm. The opening goal came after Gus Bahoken had clumsily fouled Miller 35 yards from goal. McAllister floated the free kick into the Livi box and Miller outjumped the static visiting defense to loop his header from 10 yards over Meldrum. With just 10 minutes on the clock, the home side doubled their lead. Mikoliunas sprinted down the right and crossed to the back post where McAllister raced in to head past Meldrum.

Sun Microsystems has launched a pay-as-you-go service allowing customers to rent massive computing power by the hour. Sun Grid charges users $1 (53p) per hour for processing and storage power on systems maintained by Sun. So-called grid computing is the latest buzzphrase in a company that views computing capacity as a crucial commodity, akin to hardware and software. Sun compared grid computing to the development of electricity. The system could mature similarly to utilities like electricity and water, said Sun's Chief Operating Officer Jonathan Schwartz. "Why build your own grid when you can use ours for a buck an hour?" he asked during a webcast launching Sun's quarterly network computing event in California.

Jamieson Issues Warning to Bigots Scotland's justice minister has warned bigoted soccer fans that she intends to hit them "where it hurts most" by banning them from matches. Cathy Jamieson stated that exclusion orders are one of a series of measures being considered in the Scottish Executive campaign against sectarianism. She praised Celtic and Rangers for their efforts in tackling the problem. However, the minister emphasized that stopping sectarian abuse associated with Old Firm matches is a key objective. Ms. Jamieson spoke ahead of the third-round Scottish Cup clash between the Glasgow clubs at Parkhead on Sunday. The sectarianism long associated with sections of the support from both clubs has become a significant target for the executive. Last week, Ms. Jamieson and First Minister Jack McConnell met supporters' representatives from both clubs to discuss the issue.

Kevin Spacey and Kate Bosworth attended the UK premiere of their new film, *Beyond the Sea*, in London's Leicester Square on Thursday. Spacey, 45, wrote, directed, and starred in the film, inspired by the life of 1950s crooner Bobby Darin. "This is my tribute to someone I think was a remarkable talent," remarked Spacey, who, as Darin, sings all 18 songs on the film's soundtrack. Bosworth, 21, plays Darin's wife, real-life Hollywood actress Sandra Dee. "I knew absolutely nothing about Bobby Darin before this film, but now I'm a huge fan," said Bosworth, who attended the premiere with her British boyfriend, Orlando Bloom.

Leeds v Saracens (Fri) Headingley Friday, 25 February 2000 GMT

The Tykes have brought in Newcastle prop Ed Kalman and Tom McGee from the Borders on loan, while fly-half Craig McMullen has joined from Narbonne. Raphael Ibanez is named at hooker for Saracens in one of four changes. Simon Raiwalui and Ben Russell are also selected in the pack, while Kevin Sorrell comes in at outside centre. Friday's game at Headingley got the go-ahead after passing an early pitch inspection.

Leeds: Balshaw; Rees, Christophers, Bell, Doherty; McMullen, Dickens; McGee, Rawlinson, Gerber; Murphy, Palmer (capt), Morgan, Parks, Popham. Replacements: Kalman, Regan, Hyde, Rigney, McMillan, Rock, Vickerman.

Home phones face an uncertain future as the fixed-line phone in your home could soon become a rarity. Research by handset maker Nokia reveals that more and more people are using their mobile phones for every call they make or receive. According to the study, over 45 million people in the UK, Germany, US, and South Korea now rely solely on mobiles. It showed that people keep their fixed-line phones due to lower call charges, but most respondents said the future is definitely mobile. The Nokia-sponsored research highlighted that mobiles and landlines were used for different purposes. Home phones were used for longer calls, while conversations on mobiles tended to be shorter, often between mobiles and friends. In the UK, 69% of participants said they preferred their fixed phone as it was still cheaper to use than a mobile.

Melzer shocks Agassi: Second seed Andre Agassi suffered a comprehensive defeat by Jurgen Melzer in the quarter-finals of the SAP Open. Agassi was frequently baffled by the Austrian's drop shots in San Jose, losing 6-3, 6-1. Defending champion and top seed Andy Roddick rallied to beat Sweden's Thomas Enqvist 3-6, 7-6 (8-6), 7-5. Meanwhile, unseeded Cyril Saulnier defeated the fourth seed Vincent Spadea 6-2, 6-4, and Tommy Haas overcame eighth seed Max Mirnyi 6-7 (2-7), 7-6 (7-3), 6-2. Melzer has now triumphed over Agassi in two of their three encounters. "I had a good game plan and executed it perfectly," he said. "It's always tough to come out and play Andre. I didn't want him to play his game. He makes you run all over like a dog on the court.

MPs Tout Lords Replacement Plan A group of MPs has intensified pressure on Tony Blair concerning House of Lords reform by publishing a comprehensive blueprint for change. The cross-party group has presented a draft bill proposing a smaller second chamber, with 70% of members elected. MPs and peers have been unable to agree on reform since 1999, when 600 hereditary peers lost their seats. The group believes it can garner support for eliminating the remaining 92 hereditary peers. The government postponed plans to remove these peers, citing unlikely success after opposition in the Lords. Tony Blair has emphasized the need for consensus on reforms. There are indications that proposals in Labour's manifesto may suggest at least altering the Lords' powers.

Disappointed Scott in solid start Allan Scott is confident of winning a medal at next week's European Indoor Championships after a solid debut on the international circuit. The 22-year-old Scot finished fourth in the 60m hurdles at the Jose M Cagigal Memorial meeting in Madrid. "It was definitely a learning curve, and I certainly haven't ruled out challenging for a medal next week," said the East Kilbride athlete. The race was won by Felipe Vivancos, who equaled the Spanish record. Sweden's Robert Kronberg was second, with Haiti's Dudley Dorival in third. Scott was slightly disappointed with his run in the final. He won his heat in 7.64secs but ran 0.04secs slower in his first IAAF Indoor Grand Prix Circuit final.

A US woman is suing Hewlett-Packard (HP), claiming its printer ink cartridges are secretly programmed to expire on a certain date. The unnamed woman from Georgia alleges that a chip inside the cartridge falsely indicates the need for refilling even when it's unnecessary. The lawsuit aims to represent anyone in the US who has purchased an HP inkjet printer since February 2001. HP, the world's largest printer company, declined to comment on the lawsuit. HP ink cartridges use chip technology to detect low ink levels and alert the user to replace the cartridge. However, the suit contends that the chips also deactivate the cartridges on a predetermined date regardless of their ink level.

Virgin Radio is set to become the first station globally to offer radio via 3G mobile devices, according to UK broadcaster Virgin Radio. Partnering with tech firm Sydus, the station will broadcast over selected 2G and high-speed 3G networks. Later this year, listeners can download software from the Virgin website that enables the service. James Cridland, head of new media at Virgin Radio, remarked, "It places radio at the heart of the 3G revolution." Virgin Radio will debut first, followed by two digital stations—Virgin Radio Classic Rock and Virgin Radio Groove. Mr. Cridland stated, "This application will enable anyone, anywhere, to listen to Virgin Radio simply with the phone in their pocket.

Roxy Music on Isle of Wight Bill Roxy Music will appear at June's Isle of Wight Music Festival, alongside Morrissey, Supergrass, and Idlewild. REM has already been confirmed as headliners for the three-day event, taking place from June 10-12. Original band members Bryan Ferry, Phil Manzanera, Andy Mackay, and Paul Thompson will perform on the Saturday night of the festival. The band is also working in the studio on new material, their first since the 1982 album Avalon. Roxy Music was formed in 1971 by Ferry, Mackay, and Brian Eno, with Manzanera joining the following year. Their first hit was 1972's Virginia Plain, with other hits including Street Life, Love is the Drug, and the 1981 John Lennon cover, Jealous Guy.

Captains lining up for aid match: Ireland's Brian O'Driscoll is one of four Six Nations captains included in the Northern Hemisphere squad for the IRB Rugby Aid match on 5 March. France's Fabien Pelous, Gordon Bullock of Scotland, and Italy's Marco Bortolami are also in the Northern party. Sir Clive Woodward will coach the Northern team against Rod Macqueen's Southern Hemisphere team in a tsunami fund-raising match at Twickenham. "I'm looking forward to working with such outstanding players," he said. It will be an opportunity for Woodward to evaluate some of his options before unveiling his British and Irish Lions touring party, who will visit New Zealand in the summer. "The game promises to be a great spectacle," he said.

At the Spirit Awards, the comedy "Sideways" dominated, winning all six of the awards for which it was nominated. It was named Best Film, while Alexander Payne won Best Director and Best Screenplay, along with writing partner Jim Taylor. It also won acting awards for stars Paul Giamatti, Thomas Haden Church, and Virginia Madsen. "Sideways" is expected to perform well at Sunday's Oscars, with five nominations. The Spirit Awards, now in their 20th year, recognize films made outside the traditional studio system and are traditionally held the day before the Oscars. Other winners included Catalina Sandino Moreno, who won Best Actress for her role as a drug smuggler in the Colombian drama "Maria Full of Grace." Moreno is also nominated for Best Actress at the Oscars. The Best First Screenplay award went to Joshua Marston for "Maria Full of Grace.

Prince was crowned the 'top music earner,' surpassing all other pop stars in 2004, including Madonna and Elton John, according to Rolling Stone magazine's annual list. The singer amassed $56.5m (£30.4m) through concerts, album sales, and publishing, primarily from his Musicology tour and album. He placed Madonna in the second spot, as she earned $54.9m (£29.5m) during her global Re-Invention tour. Simon and Garfunkel, veterans of the industry, were 10th, with their comeback tour earning them $24.9m (£13.4m) last year. "Prince returned to center stage after a decade in the commercial wilderness," the magazine noted. His 2004 tour grossed $90.3m (£48.5m) in ticket sales, alongside selling 1.9 million copies of his latest album, Musicology.

Walmart fights back at accusers—two major U.S. companies have launched advertising campaigns to "set the record straight" about their products and corporate behavior. The world's largest retailer, Walmart, took out more than 100 full-page ads in national newspapers. The group is trying to address criticism over its pay deals, benefits package, and promotion strategy. Meanwhile, pharmaceuticals group Eli Lilly is planning a campaign against "false" claims about its product Prozac. Walmart kicked off the effort with ads in newspapers like The Wall Street Journal, using an open letter from company president Lee Scott, stating it was time for the public to hear the "unfiltered truth." "There are lots of 'urban legends' these days about Walmart, but facts are facts.

The Tories outlined policing plans in which local communities would be asked to go to the polls to elect their own area police commissioner, under plans unveiled by the Conservatives. Party leader Michael Howard said the new role would replace "inconspicuous" police authorities. He stated the new office would not supersede the role of a chief constable. The Lib Dems said the plan could let extreme groups run policing, while Labour criticized "extravagant" Tory promises on policing. Responding to the plans, the chairman of the Police Federation of England and Wales, which represents rank-and-file officers, said it was essential operational independence was retained. Jan Berry said: "It is a service, not a political football to be kicked around every time an election approaches." She warned, "These plans could result in those with extreme political views dictating what actually happens on the ground.

At a glance: Tory health checks. The UK’s opposition Conservatives have unveiled plans to introduce health checks for immigrants if they win the general election. Here's a guide to the plan: People coming to live and work in Britain from outside the EU. If they plan to stay six months or more and are from a country with high rates of TB, they would need a chest X-ray and further tests if appropriate. All individuals from outside the European Union who wish to remain for a year or more will be required to undergo a full medical examination. Tuberculosis, Hepatitis B, and HIV. A positive TB test would automatically result in visa applications being denied. All other conditions would be addressed on a case-by-case basis.

Paris promise raises Welsh hopes: Has there been a better Six Nations match than Saturday's epic in Paris? And can the Welsh revival continue all the way to a first Grand Slam since 1978? Those are the two questions occupying not just Wales supporters but rugby fans as a whole after a scintillating display in Paris. Welsh legend Mervyn Davies, a member of two out of three Grand Slam-winning sides of the 1970s, hailed it as "one of the great performances of the past three decades." Martyn Williams, Wales' two-try scorer on the day, called it "one of the most surreal games I have ever played in." A crestfallen France coach, Bernard Laporte, simply observed: "There was a French half and there was a Welsh half.

Doves soar to UK album summit as Manchester rock band Doves have entered the UK album chart at number one with their new release, Some Cities. The trio replace the flamboyant US act Scissor Sisters at the top. The album follows the single "Black and White Town," which reached number six. R&B star Nelly has the new number one single with "Over and Over," which sees him team up with Tim McGraw. Girls Aloud, Akon, and Kaiser Chiefs all have new singles in the top ten, as do Futureheads and Usher. The latest Elvis Presley re-release, "(Marie's the Name) His Latest Flame," entered the chart at number three, one place ahead of Girls Aloud's "Wake Me Up." Hip-hop performer Akon's "Locked Up" is at number five, while the hotly-tipped Leeds band Kaiser Chiefs have their second chart hit at number six with "Oh My God.

Davies favors Gloucester future; Wales hooker Mefin Davies is likely to stay with the English side Gloucester despite reported interest from the Neath-Swansea Ospreys. BBC Wales understands the Ospreys are interested in the 32-year-old, but that he would prefer to stay where he is. Davies, one of the stars of Saturday's RBS Six Nations win over England, is only on a year contract at Kingsholm. However, the hooker has proved his worth to the Zurich Premiership side and is likely to get a new deal next season. The summer demise of the Celtic Warriors region left Davies in the cold and forced him to take a semi-professional contract with Neath RFC. Although he got match time with the Ospreys at the request of the Wales management, he admitted before his move to Gloucester that he was angry with the way he was treated.

Cabinet anger at Brown cash raid ministers are unhappy about plans to use Whitehall cash to keep council tax bills down, local government minister Nick Raynsford has acknowledged. Gordon Brown reallocated £512m from central to local government budgets in his pre-budget report on Thursday. Mr. Raynsford said he had held some "pretty frank discussions" with fellow ministers over the plans. However, he stated that local governments must deliver good services without significant council tax increases. The central government cash is part of a £1bn package to help local authorities in England keep next year's council tax rises below 5%, in what is likely to be a general election year. Mr. Raynsford said nearly all central government departments had an interest in well-run local authorities.

Israeli club look to Africa as four African players, including Zimbabwe goalkeeper Energy Murambadoro, are all ready to play for Israeli club Hapoel Bnei Sakhnin in the UEFA Cup. Bnei Sakhnin are the first Arab side ever to play in European competition and will face English Premiership side Newcastle United in the first round. Warriors' goalkeeper Murambadoro, who made a name for himself at the African Nations Cup finals in Tunisia, helped Bnei Sakhnin overcome Albania's Partizani Tirana 6-1 in the previous round. Murambadoro moved to Israel recently after a brief stint with South African club Hellenic. The club won the Israeli Cup final last season and is based in Sakhnin, near Haifa. The club has a strong ethic and are high-profile promoters of peace and co-operation within Israel.

Reducing the drink-drive limit by a third could save more lives than previously believed, a report states. Research from University College London suggests that lowering the limit from 80mg to 50mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood would save 65 lives annually. These findings are published by the Parliamentary Advisory Council for Transport Safety as MPs are set to vote on the government's road safety bill. The bill addresses changes to speeding fines but excludes the drink-drive limit. Research by transport expert Professor Richard Allsop indicates that reducing the limit would also result in 230 fewer serious injuries on UK roads compared to 2003. He estimates this could save the country £119m yearly. A previous estimate from a 1998 Department of Transport document suggested such a change could save 50 lives annually.

This paper presents a millimeter-scale CMOS 64$\times$64 single charged particle radiation detector system for external beam cancer radiotherapy. A 1$\times$1 $\mu m^2$ diode measures energy deposition by a single charged particle in the depletion region, and the array design provides a large detection area of 512$\times$512 $\mu m^2$. Instead of sensing the voltage drop caused by radiation, the proposed system measures the pulse width, i.e., the time it takes for the voltage to return to its baseline. This eliminates the need for power-hungry and large analog-to-digital converters. A prototype ASIC is fabricated in TSMC 65 nm LP CMOS process and consumes an average static power of 0.535 mW under a 1.2 V analog and digital power supply. The functionality of the whole system is successfully verified in a clinical 67.5 MeV proton beam setting.

The controllability of autonomous vehicle (AV) routing has been shown to enhance network efficiency by mitigating the effects of selfish routing. However, assuming that AVs would willingly allow external control by a central agency is impractical. In this paper, we introduce a combined routing and pricing control scheme designed to encourage AVs to adopt centrally controlled system optimal (SO) routing through toll savings. Meanwhile, user equilibrium (UE)-seeking AVs and human-driven vehicles (HVs) are subject to congestion charges. The problem is formulated as a bi-level optimization: dynamic tolls are optimized at the upper level, while the lower level features a mixed equilibrium simulation-based dynamic traffic assignment model, incorporating a mixed fleet of AVs and HVs.

Optomechanics and electromechanics have enabled the preparation of macroscopic mechanical oscillators in their quantum ground states, quadrature squeezed states, and entangled states of motion. Beyond coaxing larger and more tangible objects into a quantum behavior regime, this new capability has inspired ideas for using mechanical oscillators in the processing and communication of quantum information and as precision force sensors operating beyond the standard quantum limit. However, the effectively linear interaction between motion and light or electricity precludes access to a broader class of quantum states of motion, such as cat states or energy squeezed states. Indeed, early optomechanical proposals noted the possibility of escaping this restriction by creating strong quadratic coupling of motion to light. Although there have been experimental demonstrations of quadratically coupled optomechanical systems, they have not yet accessed nonclassical states of motion.

Online reviews provide product evaluations for customers to make informed decisions. Unfortunately, these evaluations can be manipulated using fake reviews ("spams") by professional spammers, who have learned increasingly insidious and powerful spamming strategies by adapting to the deployed detectors. Spamming strategies are hard to capture, as they can vary quickly over time, differ among spammers and target products, and, more critically, remain unknown in most cases. Furthermore, most existing detectors focus on detection accuracy, which is not well-aligned with the goal of maintaining the trustworthiness of product evaluations. To address these challenges, we formulate a minimax game where the spammers and spam detectors compete with each other on their practical goals, which are not solely based on detection accuracy. Nash equilibria of the game lead to stable detectors that are agnostic to any mixed detection strategies.

We developed single-shot shaped pulses for ultra-high fidelity (uh-fidelity) population transfer in a 3-level quantum system with lambda configuration. To ensure high fidelity, we use the Lewis-Riesenfeld (L-R) method to derive a family of solutions for exact transfer, where the solutions follow a single dynamical mode of the L-R invariant. Among this family, we identify a tracking solution with a single parameter to control the fidelity of the transfer, the population of the excited state, and robustness. We define a measure of robustness as the minimum percentile deviation on the pulse areas at which infidelity rises above \(10^{-4}\). The robustness of our shaped pulses is found superior to that of Gaussian and adiabatically-optimized pulses for moderate pulse areas.

In this paper, we explore the landscape of the population negative log-likelihood function of Gaussian mixture models with various components. Due to nonconvexity, multiple local minima exist that are not globally optimal, even when the mixture is well-separated. We demonstrate that all local minima share a similar structure that partially identifies the component centers of the true mixture. Each local minimum involves a non-overlapping combination of fitting multiple Gaussians to a single true component and fitting a single Gaussian to multiple true components. Our findings apply to the setting where the true mixture components satisfy a certain separation condition and remain valid even when the number of components is over- or under-specified. For Gaussian mixtures with three components, we obtain more precise results in relation to the separation between the components.

We examine the connection between two constructions of the mirror partner for the Calabi-Yau orbifold. This orbifold is defined as a quotient by a suitable subgroup $g$ of the phase symmetries of the hypersurface $ x_m $ in the weighted projective space, determined by a quasi-homogeneous polynomial $w_m$. The first, Berglund-Hübsch-Krawitz (BHK) construction, uses another weighted projective space and the quotient of a new hypersurface $x_{m^t}$ within it by a dual group $g^t$. In the second, Batyrev construction, the mirror partner is formulated as a hypersurface in the toric variety defined by the reflexive polytope dual to the polytope associated with the original Calabi-Yau orbifold. We provide simple evidence for the equivalence of these two constructions.
