In this work, a generalization of the study of human gait was developed using existing models in the literature, such as those by Keller and Kockshenev. In this hybrid model, a strategy of metabolic energy minimization is combined in a race process with a non-linear description of the movement of the center of mass's libration, aiming to replicate the behavior of the walk-run transition. The results of experimental data for different speed regimes demonstrate that the perimeter of the mass center's trajectory is a significant factor in quantifying this dynamic. An experimental procedure was conducted in collaboration with the research group in biomedical engineering, basic sciences, and laboratories of the Manuela Beltrán University in Bogotá, Colombia.

We present a new mixed variable symplectic (mvs) integrator for planetary systems, capable of fully resolving close encounters. The method relies on a time regularization that maintains the stability properties of symplectic integrators while also reducing the effective step size when two planets encounter each other. We employ a high-order mvs scheme, allowing integration with large time steps when far from close encounters. This algorithm can resolve nearly exact collisions (e.g., with a mutual separation of a fraction of the physical radius) while using the same time-step as in weakly perturbed problems like the solar system. We demonstrate the long-term behavior on systems of six super-Earths experiencing strong scattering over 50 kyr. We compare our algorithm to hybrid methods such as Mercury and show that for an equivalent cost, we achieve significantly better energy conservation.

Entanglement is a crucial resource for quantum information processing. A widely used tool for detecting entanglement is the entanglement witness, where the measurement of the witness operator is guaranteed to be positive for all separable states and can be negative for certain entangled states. In practice, due to the exponentially increasing Hilbert space dimension with respect to system size, constructing an efficient entanglement witness for general multipartite entangled states is very challenging. For $n$-partite Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger (GHZ)-like states, the most robust witness scheme requires $n+1$ local measurement settings and can tolerate up to $1/2$ white noise. By comparison, the most efficient witness for GHZ-like states only needs two local measurement settings and can tolerate up to $1/3$ white noise.

Within general relativity, the unique stationary solution of an isolated black hole is the Kerr spacetime, which has a distinct multipolar structure determined only by its mass and spin. We develop a general method to extract the multipole moments of any arbitrary stationary spacetimes and apply it to a vast family of horizonless microstate geometries. These can disrupt the axial and equatorial symmetry of the Kerr metric and exhibit a significantly richer multipolar structure, providing a means to constrain fuzzball models phenomenologically. We find numerical evidence suggesting that all multipole moments are typically greater (in absolute value) than those of a Kerr black hole with the same mass and spin. Current measurements of the quadrupole moment of black-hole candidates could impose only mild constraints on fuzzballs, while future gravitational-wave detections of extreme mass-ratio inspirals with the space mission LISA will enhance these bounds significantly.

Reasoning about graphs evolving over time is a challenging concept in many fields, such as bioinformatics, physics, and social networks. We consider a common scenario in which edges can be short-term interactions (e.g., messaging) or long-term structural connections (e.g., friendship). In practice, humans often specify long-term edges. Human-specified edges can be both costly to produce and suboptimal for the downstream task. To address these issues, we propose a model based on temporal point processes and variational autoencoders that learns to infer temporal attention between nodes by observing node communication. As temporal attention drives between-node feature propagation, leveraging the dynamics of node interactions to learn this key component offers more flexibility while simultaneously avoiding issues associated with human-specified edges.

Observations of thermally driven transverse vibration of a photonic crystal waveguide (pcw) are reported. The pcw comprises two parallel nanobeams with a 240 nm vacuum gap between them. Models are developed and validated for the transduction of beam motion to phase and amplitude modulation of a weak optical probe propagating in a guided mode (gm) of the pcw for probe frequencies far from and near to the dielectric band edge. Since our pcw is designed for near-field atom trapping, this research provides a foundation for evaluating potential deleterious effects of thermal motion on optical atomic traps near the surfaces of pcws. Longer-term goals include achieving strong atom-mediated links between individual phonons and single photons propagating in the gms of the pcw, thereby enabling opto-mechanics at the quantum level with atoms, photons, and phonons.

We establish natural splittings for the values of global Mackey functors at orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups. In particular, the restriction homomorphisms between the orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups of adjacent dimensions are naturally split epimorphisms. The interest in the splitting arises from equivariant stable homotopy theory. The equivariant stable homotopy groups of every global spectrum form a global Mackey functor, so the splittings imply that certain long exact homotopy group sequences decompose into short exact sequences. For the real and complex global Thom spectra $\mathbf{mo}$ and $\mathbf{mu}$, the splittings imply the regularity of various Euler classes related to the tautological representations of $o(n)$ and $u(n)$.

Baryonic feedback effects cause a suppression of the weak lensing angular power spectrum on small scales. The poorly constrained shape and amplitude of this suppression are significant sources of uncertainty for upcoming cosmological weak lensing surveys such as Euclid or LSST. In this first paper in a series of two, we use simulations to create a Euclid-like tomographic mock data-set for the cosmic shear power spectrum and the corresponding covariance matrix, both corrected for baryonic effects following the baryonification method of Schneider et al. (2019). Additionally, we develop an emulator to provide fast predictions of the baryonic power suppression, allowing us to conduct a likelihood inference analysis for a standard $\lambda$CDM cosmology with both cosmological and astrophysical parameters.

Spontaneous conversations in real-world settings, such as those found in child-centered recordings, rank among the most challenging audio files to process. Nevertheless, building speech processing models that handle such diverse conditions would be particularly useful for language acquisition studies. Researchers are interested in the quantity and quality of the speech that children hear and produce, as well as early diagnosis and the effects of remediation. In this paper, we present our approach to designing an open-source neural network to classify audio segments into vocalizations produced by the child wearing the recording device, vocalizations by other children, adult male speech, and adult female speech. To achieve this, we gathered diverse child-centered corpora, totaling 260 hours of recordings and covering 10 languages.

Density-based clustering relies on linking groups to specific features of the probability distribution underlying the data. Referring to a true, yet unknown, population structure frames the clustering problem in an inferential setting, where ideal population clustering is defined by the partition induced by the true density function. The nonparametric formulation of this approach, known as modal clustering, associates groups with the domains of attraction of density modes. Operationally, a nonparametric density estimate is needed, and selecting the appropriate amount of smoothing, which governs the shape of the density and potentially the modal structure, is crucial to identifying the final partition. This work addresses the issue of density estimation for modal clustering from an asymptotic perspective.

The tails of diboson production at the LHC are sensitive to the interference between Standard Model and higher dimension operators parameterizing the effects of heavy new physics. However, helicity selection rules for the diboson scattering amplitudes set an obstruction to the naïve interference contributions of dimension-six operators, causing the total diboson rate correction's leading contribution to cancel. In this case, carefully measuring the azimuthal decay angles "resurrects" the interference, recouping sensitivity to the "non-interfering" operators. We explore these signatures in detail and find that the EFT uncertainties associated with higher-dimensional operators are uniquely well-suppressed by the construction of an asymmetry variable, which is only generated by these non-interfering operators, relegating the effects of higher-dimensional, interfering operators to the same status as statistical errors in this observable.

Causal inference from observational data is a key goal of many analyses in the health and social sciences. However, academic statistics has often been skeptical of analyses with a causal objective. The introduction of the term "data science" offers a historic chance to redefine data analysis to naturally include causal inference from observational data. Like others before, we categorize the scientific contributions of data science into three task classes: description, prediction, and counterfactual prediction (including causal inference). An explicit classification of data science tasks is necessary to discuss the data, assumptions, and analytics needed for each task. We argue that failing to adequately describe the role of expert knowledge in data analysis is a source of widespread misunderstandings about data science.

The weak gravity conjecture (WGC) demands the existence of superextremal particles in any consistent quantum theory of gravity. The standard belief is that these particles are introduced to ensure that extremal black holes are either unstable or marginally stable, but it is not clear what is wrong if this doesn't occur. This note shows that, for a generic Einstein quantum theory of gravity in AdS, exact stability of extremal black branes is in tension with rigorously proven quantum information theorems about entanglement entropy. Avoiding the contradiction leads to a nonperturbative version of the WGC, which reduces to the usual statement at weak coupling. The argument is general, and it does not rely on either supersymmetry or a particular UV completion, assuming only the validity of Einsteinian gravity, effective field theory, and holography.

Understanding how strongly correlated two-dimensional (2D) systems can give rise to unconventional superconductivity with high critical temperatures is one of the major unsolved problems in condensed matter physics. Ultracold 2D Fermi gases have emerged as clean and controllable model systems to study the interplay of strong correlations and reduced dimensionality, but direct evidence of superfluidity in these systems has been elusive. Here, we demonstrate superfluidity in an ultracold 2D Fermi gas by moving a periodic potential through the system and observing no dissipation below a critical velocity \(v_{\rm c}\). We measure \(v_{\rm c}\) as a function of interaction strength and find a peak in the crossover regime between bosonic and fermionic superfluidity. Our measurement establishes ultracold Fermi gases as a powerful tool for studying the influence of reduced dimensionality on correlated superfluids.

Ordinary differential equations (ODEs) are mathematical models used across many disciplines such as climatology, bioinformatics, and chemical engineering due to their intuitive appeal for modeling. Despite the wide application of ODEs, the frequent absence of analytic solutions makes it challenging to estimate parameters from data, particularly when models involve numerous variables and parameters. This paper proposes a Bayesian ODE parameter estimation algorithm that is both fast and accurate, even for complex models. The method approximates an ODE model with a state-space model using equations from a numerical solver, allowing for swift estimation by avoiding computation of a complete numerical solution in the likelihood. The posterior is derived using a variational Bayes method, specifically, the approximate Riemannian conjugate gradient method (Honkela et al.).

We investigate the transport properties and superconducting proximity effect in NSN junctions formed by a time-reversal symmetry broken Weyl semimetal (WSM) in proximity to an s-wave superconductor. Our findings indicate that the differential conductance and induced pairing amplitudes are strongly influenced by the angle between the junction direction in real space and the axis separating the Weyl nodes in momentum space. We identify the effect of a chiral chemical potential, namely, the electron population imbalance between Weyl nodes of opposite chirality, on the transport characteristics of the junction. Notably, we observe a net spin polarization of Cooper pairs generated via Andreev reflection in the two WSM regions. This spin polarization is opposite in the two WSM regions and highly sensitive to the chirality imbalance and excitation energy.

Metal ion implantation into ceramics is a proven and controllable technique for tailoring the surface electrical conductivity of ceramic pieces, and this method has been employed in many applications. Importantly, it offers a way to grade the voltage drop across high voltage insulators, thereby increasing the maximum operational voltage that can be applied without surface flashover. However, a concern is the long-term stability of the implantation-induced conductivity, especially if the implanted metal species oxidizes easily. Here we report on our study of the long-term behavior of the surface conductivity of titanium-implanted alumina. The results indicate that after an initial drop of up to 40% in the first few weeks post-implantation, the conductivity shows only a very slow decrease of about 10% over the following year.

We introduce a novel Skyrme-like conserved current in the effective theory of pions and vector mesons based on the concept of hidden local symmetry. The associated charge is equivalent to the Skyrmion charge for any smooth configuration. Additionally, there exist singular configurations that can be identified as \( n_f=1 \) baryons charged under the new symmetry. With this identification, the vector mesons act as the Chern-Simons vector fields residing on the quantum Hall droplet that forms the \( n_f=1 \) baryon. We propose that this current is the correct effective expression for the baryon current at low energies. This proposal provides a unified picture for the two types of baryons, allowing them to transform continuously into one another naturally. Moreover, Chern-Simons dualities on the droplet can be interpreted through Seiberg-like duality between gluons and vector mesons.

Interfacial spin-orbit coupling in Josephson junctions offers an intriguing way to combine anomalous Hall and Josephson physics in a single device. We theoretically study how the superposition of both effects impacts superconductor/ferromagnetic insulator/superconductor junctions' transport properties. Transverse momentum-dependent skew tunneling of Cooper pairs through the spin-active ferromagnetic insulator interface creates sizable transverse Hall supercurrents, which we refer to as anomalous Josephson Hall effect currents. We generalize the Furusaki-Tsukada formula, originally established to quantify usual (tunneling) Josephson current flows, to evaluate the transverse current components and demonstrate that their amplitudes are widely adjustable through the spin-orbit coupling strengths or the superconducting phase difference across the junction. As a clear spectroscopic fingerprint of Josephson junctions, well-localized subgap bound states form around the interface.

Following the suggestion from the Monte-Carlo experiments in Jiménez, J. of Turbul. (2020), that dipoles are as crucial to the dynamics of decaying two-dimensional turbulence as individual vortex cores, it is found that the kinetic energy of this flow is carried by elongated streams formed by the concatenation of dipoles. Vortices separate into a group of small fast-moving cores and another group of larger slowly moving ones, which can be described as 'frozen' into a slowly evolving 'crystal.' The kinematics of both groups are very different, and only the former is self-similar. The latter is responsible for most kinetic energy of the flow, and its vortices form the dipoles and the streams. Mechanisms are discussed for the growth of this slow component.

Continuous-time quantum walks have proven to be a highly effective framework for designing various quantum algorithms. Typically, the runtime of quantum algorithms in this framework is characterized by the quantum hitting time: the time required for the quantum walk to locate a vertex of interest with high probability. In this article, we offer improved upper bounds for the quantum hitting time applicable to several ctqw-based quantum algorithms. Specifically, we apply our techniques to the glued-trees problem, enhancing their hitting time upper bound by a polynomial factor: from $o(n^5)$ to $o(n^2\log n)$. Moreover, our methods also facilitate an exponential improvement in the dependence on precision for the continuous-time quantum walk-based algorithm to find a marked node on any ergodic, reversible Markov chain by Chakraborty et al.

Extreme mass ratio inspirals (EMRIs) can be classified as dry EMRIs and wet EMRIs based on their formation mechanisms. Dry (or "loss-cone") EMRIs, previously considered the main EMRI sources for the Laser Interferometer Space Antenna, are primarily produced by multi-body scattering in the nuclear star cluster and gravitational capture. In this letter, we highlight an alternative EMRI formation channel: wet EMRI formation assisted by the accretion flow around accreting galactic-center massive black holes (MBHs). In this channel, the accretion disk captures stellar-mass black holes initially moving on inclined orbits and then drives them to migrate towards the MBH. This process significantly boosts the formation rate of EMRIs in such galaxies.

When a new user signs up on a website, we typically have no information about them, including no interactions with items, no user profile, and no social links with other users. Despite this, we expect our recommender systems to attract the users right away so that they choose to stay on the site and become active users. This challenge is known as the new user cold-start problem and is vital for a company's growth and even survival. Existing solutions for user cold-start recommendations often require extra effort from users, such as setting up interviews, or rely on side information like user demographics, locations, social relations, etc. However, users might be reluctant to participate in interviews, and side information is often unavailable for cold-start users.

Deep learning has solved many problems that heuristic algorithms cannot. It has also been successfully applied in wireless communications, even though current radio systems are well-understood and optimal algorithms exist for many tasks. While some improvements have been made by learning individual parts of a receiver, a more effective approach is to jointly learn the entire receiver. This, however, often results in a challenging nonlinear problem, for which the optimal solution is difficult to implement. To address this, we propose a deep fully convolutional neural network, deeprx, which processes the entire receiver pipeline from frequency domain signal stream to uncoded bits in a 5G-compliant manner. We ensure accurate channel estimation by constructing the input of the convolutional neural network in a very specific way using both data and pilot symbols.

Mutation-based fuzzing typically employs an initial set of non-crashing seed inputs (a corpus) to create new inputs via mutation. A corpus of potential seeds often includes thousands of similar inputs. This lack of diversity can result in wasted fuzzing efforts due to exhaustive mutations from available seeds. To mitigate this, fuzzers offer distillation tools (e.g., afl-cmin) to select the smallest subset of seeds triggering the same range of instrumentation data points as the full corpus. Common practice suggests minimizing seed quantity and cumulative size leads to more efficient fuzzing, which we explore systematically. We present results from 34+ CPU-years of fuzzing using five distillation approaches to understand their impact on finding bugs in real-world software.

In this paper, we investigate multi-agent discrete-event systems with partial observation. The agents are divided into several groups, each of which has agents with similar (isomorphic) state transition structures, allowing them to be relabeled into the same template. Based on this template, we design a scalable supervisor whose state size and computational cost remain independent of the number of agents, even under partial observation. This scalable supervisor doesn't require recomputation regardless of how many agents are added to or removed from the system. We extend our earlier results to partial observation by proposing sufficient conditions for safety and maximal permissiveness of the least restrictive scalable supervisor at the template level. An example is provided to illustrate the proposed scalable supervisory synthesis.

Electric network frequency (ENF) fluctuations serve as a powerful tool in multimedia forensics. An efficient approach for ENF estimation is introduced with temporal windowing using the filter-bank Capon spectral estimator. A type of Gohberg-Semencul factorization of the model covariance matrix is utilized due to the Toeplitz structure of this matrix. Additionally, this approach employs, for the first time in the field of ENF, a temporal window—not necessarily rectangular—prior to spectral estimation. Krylov matrices are used for fast implementation of matrix inversions. The proposed approach surpasses state-of-the-art methods in ENF estimation when a short time window of one second is applied in power recordings. In speech recordings, the proposed approach delivers highly accurate results regarding both time complexity and accuracy.

The direpack package aims to integrate a set of modern statistical dimension reduction techniques into the Python ecosystem as a unified, consistent package. The dimension reduction methods included are classified into three categories: projection pursuit-based dimension reduction, sufficient dimension reduction, and robust M-estimators for dimension reduction. Additionally, regularized regression estimators utilizing these reduced dimension spaces are provided, ranging from classical principal component regression to sparse partial robust M regression. The package also offers a collection of classical and robust pre-processing utilities, including generalized spatial signs, alongside dedicated plotting and cross-validation utilities. Finally, direpack is designed to be compatible with the scikit-learn API, enabling the seamless incorporation of estimators into (statistical and/or machine) learning pipelines within that framework.

The nonlinear fluorescence emission has been widely applied for high spatial resolution optical imaging. Here, we studied the fluorescence anomalous saturating effect of the nitrogen vacancy defect in diamond. A reduction in fluorescence was observed with high-power laser excitation. This effect increased the nonlinearity of the fluorescence emission and altered the spatial frequency distribution of the fluorescence image. We employed a differential excitation protocol to extract high spatial frequency information. By modulating the power of the excitation laser, the spatial resolution of imaging was improved by approximately 1.6 times compared to confocal microscopy. Due to the simplicity of both the experimental setup and data processing, we anticipate this method can enhance the spatial resolution of sensing and biological labeling using defects in solids.

When random effects are correlated with sample design variables, using individual survey weights (constructed to be inversely proportional to the unit survey inclusion probabilities) to form a pseudo-likelihood no longer yields asymptotically unbiased inference. We construct a weight-exponentiated formulation for the random effects distribution that achieves unbiased inference for generating hyperparameters of the random effects. We contrast our approach with frequentist methods relying on numerical integration to show that only the Bayesian method achieves both unbiased estimation concerning the sampling design distribution and consistency with respect to the population generating distribution. Our simulations and real data example for a survey of business establishments demonstrate the utility of our approach across various modeling formulations and sampling designs. This work acts as a culmination of recent efforts that integrate traditional survey estimation approaches with the Bayesian modeling paradigm and provides a bridge across the two rich but disparate sub-fields.

Low-symmetry 2D materials—such as ReS$_2$ and ReSe$_2$ monolayers, black phosphorus monolayers, group-IV monochalcogenide monolayers, borophene, among others—possess more complex atomistic structures than the honeycomb lattices of graphene, hexagonal boron nitride, and transition metal dichalcogenides. The reduced symmetries of these emerging materials lead to inhomogeneous electronic, optical, valley, and spin responses, as well as entirely new properties like ferroelasticity, ferroelectricity, magnetism, spin-wave phenomena, large nonlinear optical properties, photogalvanic effects, and superconductivity. Novel electronic topological properties, nonlinear elastic properties, and structural phase transformations can also occur due to low symmetry. The "Beyond Graphene: Low-Symmetry and Anisotropic 2D Materials" special topic was assembled to highlight recent experimental and theoretical research on these emerging materials.

Orientational dynamics in the isotropic phase of a comb-shaped nematic polymer with mesogenic and functional side groups were studied using the Kerr effect and dielectric spectroscopy. For the first time, it was discovered that in a mesogenic polymer, unlike low-molecular-weight mesogens, the relaxation of the electric birefringence of a melt above the nematic-isotropic phase transition temperature can be described by a sum of several exponential processes, two of which are pivotal. These main processes replace each other over a temperature range of about fifty degrees. Dielectric spectroscopy also allowed the identification of two processes of orientational relaxation: the first is due to the rotation of side mesogenic groups, and the second is associated with the motion of main chain segments.

Deep hashing methods have demonstrated excellent retrieval accuracy and efficiency in large-scale image retrieval. Optimizing discrete hash bits remains a primary focus within deep hashing methods. A typical strategy in these methods is to employ an activation function, such as $\operatorname{sigmoid}(\cdot)$ or $\operatorname{tanh}(\cdot)$, and minimize quantization loss to approximate discrete values. However, this approach can cause more hash bits to become stuck in the incorrect saturated area of the activation functions and unable to escape. We refer to this issue as the "dead bits problem (dbp)." Moreover, the current quantization loss exacerbates dbp. In this paper, we propose a simple yet effective gradient amplifier, applied before activation functions, to mitigate dbp.

We analyze the phenomenology of a hypercharge-zero su(2) triplet scalar, motivated by two-step electroweak symmetry breaking. We explore the scenarios where the triplets are either stable, contributing to dark matter density, or decay via mixing with the standard model Higgs boson. The former scenario is constrained by disappearing charged track searches at the LHC and dark matter direct detection experiments, whereas the latter scenario is constrained by existing multilepton collider searches. We find that a two-step electroweak phase transition involving a stable triplet with a negative quadratic term is ruled out by direct detection searches, while an unstable triplet with a mass less than $230\ \mathrm{GeV}$ is excluded at the $95\%$ confidence level.

This paper demonstrates that the eccentric debris rings observed around the stars Fomalhaut and HD 202628 are narrower than anticipated in the standard eccentric planet perturbation scenario (sometimes referred to as "pericenter glow"). The conventional scenario suggests an initially circular and narrow belt of planetesimals at semi-major axis $a$, whose eccentricity is heightened to $e_f$ after the gas disc disperses due to secular perturbations from an eccentric planet, resulting in a belt of width $2ae_f$. With a slight modification of this scenario, narrower belts can emerge if the planetesimals are initially eccentric, possibly due to earlier planet perturbations during the gas-rich protoplanetary disc phase. Alternatively, a primordial eccentricity could arise from instabilities that increase the disc eccentricity, without the need for any planets.

An electron is typically considered to have only one type of kinetic energy, but could it possess more, for its spin and charge, or by exciting other electrons? In one dimension (1D), the physics of interacting electrons is effectively described at low energies by the Tomonaga-Luttinger-Liquid (TLL) model, yet little has been observed experimentally beyond this linear regime. Here, we report measurements of many-body modes in 1D gated wires using a tunneling spectroscopy technique. We observe two separate Fermi seas at high energies, associated with spin and charge excitations, alongside the emergence of three additional 1D 'replica' modes that strengthen with decreasing wire length. The effective interaction strength in the wires is varied by adjusting the amount of 1D inter-subband screening by over 45%.

$context$. The assembly history of the Milky Way is currently being unveiled thanks to data from the $Gaia$ mission. It is likely that our galaxy's globular cluster system has followed an equally intricate formation path. $aims$. To constrain this formation path, we explore the link between globular clusters and the known merging events the Milky Way has experienced. $methods$. We combined the kinematic information provided by $Gaia$ for almost all galactic clusters with the largest sample of cluster ages available, carefully correcting for systematic errors. To identify clusters with a common origin, we analyzed their dynamical properties, particularly in the space of integrals of motion. $results$. We find that about 40% of the clusters likely formed in situ.

Estimating the intrinsic dimension of a dataset is a fundamental step in most dimensionality reduction techniques. This article introduces 'intrinsic,' an R package that implements novel state-of-the-art likelihood-based estimators of a dataset's intrinsic dimension. Specifically, the methods included in this package are the two-nn, gride, and hidalgo models. To make these estimators easily accessible, the package provides several high-level, intuitive functions that depend on a comprehensive set of efficient, low-level routines. Intrinsic encompasses models in two categories: homogeneous and heterogeneous intrinsic dimension estimators. The first category includes the two-nn and gride models. The functions for these two methods perform inference under both frequentist and Bayesian frameworks. In the second category is hidalgo, a Bayesian mixture model, for which an efficient Gibbs sampler is implemented.

Spintronic nanodevices exhibit ultrafast nonlinear dynamic and recurrence behaviors on a nanosecond scale, promising to enable spintronic reservoir computing (RC) systems. Here, two physical RC systems based on a single magnetic skyrmion memristor (MSM) and 24 spin-torque nano-oscillators (STNOs) were proposed and modeled to process image classification tasks and nonlinear dynamic system prediction, respectively. Based on our micromagnetic simulation results regarding the nonlinear responses of MSM and STNO with current pulse stimulation, the handwritten digit recognition task demonstrates that an RC system using a single MSM performs outstandingly in image classification. Additionally, complex unknown nonlinear dynamic problems can also be effectively solved by a physical RC system consisting of 24 STNOs, as confirmed in a second-order nonlinear dynamic system and NARMA10 tasks.

Ranking algorithms are crucial in online platforms, from search engines to recommender systems. In this paper, we identify a surprising consequence of popularity-based rankings: the fewer the items reporting a given signal, the higher the share of overall traffic they attract. This few-get-richer effect emerges in settings with few distinct classes of items (e.g., left-leaning versus right-leaning news sources), and items are ranked based on popularity. We demonstrate analytically that the few-get-richer effect arises when people tend to click on top-ranked items and have varied preferences for item classes. Using simulations, we analyze how the strength of the effect changes with assumptions about the setting and human behavior. We test our predictions experimentally in an online experiment with human participants. Our findings have important implications for understanding the spread of misinformation.

Weight pruning is widely recognized as a straightforward and effective method to eliminate redundancy in deep neural networks (DNN), achieving acceleration on various platforms. However, most pruning techniques essentially involve trade-offs between model accuracy and regularity, leading to impaired inference accuracy and limited on-device acceleration. To address this issue, we introduce a new sparsity dimension: pattern-based sparsity, comprising pattern and connectivity sparsity, which is both highly accurate and hardware-friendly. With carefully designed patterns, our proposed pruning unprecedentedly and consistently achieves accuracy enhancement and improved feature extraction on different DNN structures and datasets. Our pattern-aware pruning framework also achieves simultaneous pattern library extraction, pattern selection, pattern and connectivity pruning, and weight training. Our approach to pattern-based sparsity naturally fits into compiler optimization for highly efficient DNN execution on mobile platforms.

Difference-in-differences analysis using a control group that differs considerably from a treated group is susceptible to bias from historical events impacting the groups differently. Constructing a more closely matched control group by matching a subset of the overall control group to the treated group can reduce bias. We examine this in simulation studies. We investigate the effect of mountaintop removal mining (MRM) on mortality using a difference-in-differences analysis that considers the increase in MRM following the 1990 Clean Air Act amendments. For a difference-in-differences analysis of the effect of MRM on mortality, we created a more closely matched control group and found a 95% confidence interval that encompasses substantial adverse effects, no effect, and small beneficial effects.

When constructing models to summarize clinical data used for simulations, it is good practice to evaluate these models for their ability to reproduce the data. This can be done through visual predictive checks (VPC), which involve (1) conducting several reproductions of the original study by simulating from the model under evaluation, (2) calculating estimates of interest for each simulated study, and (3) comparing the distribution of these estimates with those from the original study. This procedure is a generic method that is generally straightforward to apply. Here, we consider applying the method to time-to-event data and examine the special case when a time-varying covariate is unknown or cannot be approximated after the event time.

Novel concepts, perspectives, and challenges in measuring and controlling an open quantum system through sequential schemes are demonstrated. We discuss how similar protocols, relying on repeated quantum measurements and dynamical decoupling control pulses, can enable one to: (i) confine and protect quantum dynamics from decoherence in accordance with Zeno physics, (ii) analytically predict the probability of a quantum system being transferred into a target quantum state through stochastic sequential measurements, and (iii) optimally reconstruct the spectral density of environmental noise sources by orthogonalizing, in the frequency domain, the filter functions driving the designed quantum sensor. Achieving these tasks will enhance our ability to observe and manipulate open quantum systems, thereby advancing quantum science and technologies.

Palms sweaty, heart racing, stomach in knots. You can't cry for help. Not only is your throat too tight to breathe, but it would be so embarrassing. No, you aren't being stalked by a monster; you're speaking in public, a fate some deem worse than death. See, when you're dead, you feel nothing; at a podium, you feel stage fright. But at some point, we've all had to communicate in front of people, so you have to try and overcome it. To start, understand what stage fright is. Humans, social animals as we are, are wired to worry about reputation. Public speaking can threaten it. Before a speech, you fret, "What if people think I'm awful and an idiot?

I can't think of anyone who has just one interest in life, dedicating themselves solely to that for the rest of their life. Around 15 percent of American workers don't have traditional full-time jobs. They're part-time, contract workers, or temps. The term "side hustle" fits this ethos where people combine various roles to make a living. The word "side hustle" has its roots in popular African American newspapers. In the 1920s, these papers used the word "hustle" to refer to some kind of scam. By the 1950s, they were using "side hustle" to refer to legitimate work, too. A side hustle is different from a second job. A second job is about necessity.

Two twin domes, two radically contrasting design cultures. One is made of thousands of steel parts, the other from a single silk thread. One is synthetic, the other organic. One is imposed on the environment, the other creates it. One is designed for nature, the other designed by it. Michelangelo remarked that when he looked at raw marble, he saw a figure struggling to be free. The chisel was Michelangelo's only tool. But living things are not chiseled; they grow. And in our smallest units of life, our cells, we carry all the information needed for every other cell to function and replicate. Tools also have consequences. Since the industrial revolution, the world of design has been dominated by the rigors of manufacturing and mass production.

Hello. My name is Simone. You know how people suggest that if you get nervous onstage, you should picture the audience naked? It's supposed to make you feel better. But I was thinking—picturing everyone naked in 2018 feels odd and inappropriate. We're working hard to move past such practices, so we need a new method for handling stage fright. I realized I'd really like to be able to look at you as much as you look at me, just to even things out a little. So, if I had way more eyeballs, we'd all be more comfortable, right?

To do two things at once is to do neither." This is often cited as a critique of multitasking and is frequently attributed to the Roman writer Publilius Syrus. However, attributions can be unreliable, and he may never have said it. Nonetheless, the question remains: is it true? It's evidently true for situations like emailing at the dinner table, texting while driving, or perhaps live tweeting at a TED Talk. But I'd argue that for certain important activities, doing two, three, or even four things at once is precisely what we should strive for. Consider Albert Einstein, who in 1905 published four remarkable scientific papers.

I know this may sound strange, but I believe robots can inspire us to become better humans. You see, I grew up in Bethlehem, Pennsylvania, the home of Bethlehem Steel. My father was an engineer, and during my childhood, he would teach me how things worked. We would build projects together, like model rockets and slot cars. Here's the go-kart we built together. That's me behind the wheel, with my sister and my best friend at the time. One day, when I was about 10 years old, he came home and announced at the dinner table that for our next project, we were going to build a robot.

Sustainability represents what is caught, where, and how. The who and the why are important to me. I want to know the people behind my dinner choices. I want to understand how I affect them and how they affect me. I want to know why they fish and how they rely on the water's bounty for their living. Understanding this enables us to view seafood not as a commodity but as an opportunity to restore our ecosystem. It allows us to celebrate the seafood we're fortunate to eat. So what do we call this? I think we call it restorative seafood. Where sustainability is the capacity to endure and maintain, restorative is the ability to replenish and progress.

The starving orphan seeking a second helping of gruel. The spinster wasting away in her tattered wedding dress. The stone-hearted miser haunted by the ghost of Christmas Past. More than a century after his death, these remain recognizable figures from the works of Charles Dickens. So striking is his literature that it gave rise to its own adjective. But what are the features of Dickens's writing that make it so special? Dickens’s fiction overflows with anticipation through brooding settings, plot twists, and mysteries. These elements of his stories kept audiences wanting more. When first published, his stories were serialized, meaning they were released a few chapters at a time in affordable literary journals and only later reprinted as books.

Shah Rukh Khan: courage, determination, and a single-minded vision. These are the qualities the greatest achievers share. These are those fearless souls for whom failure is not an option. What appears to us as an unconquerable sea, is, to our next speaker, an irresistible stage she was born to perform on. So let's dive into the story of our fearless speaker, Bhakti Sharma, who's making waves in the world of long-distance swimming. Bhakti Sharma. (applause) Bhakti Sharma: imagine, in the scorching Rajasthan heat, on a hot summer afternoon, a two-and-a-half-year-old riding on a moped behind her mom, not knowing where they were headed. And 20 minutes later, that child finds herself completely submerged in water.

I am going to discuss a technology currently under development at Oxford that we believe will revolutionize the way computer games and Hollywood films are produced. This technology involves simulating humans, including a virtual body and a simulated nervous system to control that body. Now, before I delve deeper into this technology, let's quickly examine current human characters in computer games. Here is a clip from a game called "Grand Theft Auto 3," which we briefly observed yesterday. As you can see, it is actually an excellent game and one of the most successful games of all time.

Like many people around the world, earlier this summer my friends and I were captivated by the Women's World Cup held in France. We watched these incredible athletes; the goals were amazing, the games were clean and engaging, and simultaneously, outside the field, these women were advocating for equal pay and, in some countries, any pay at all for their sport. Due to our obsession, we wanted to watch the games live, and we decided that one of the Spanish-speaking networks in the US was the best place to start. It wasn't until a few games into the tournament that a friend remarked, "Why does it feel like everything I'm seeing is commercials for makeup, household cleaning products, and diets?

I want to talk about the future of money. Let's begin with a story about a culture in Micronesia in the early 1900s, called the Yap. I mention the Yap because their form of money is fascinating. They used limestone discs called rai stones. The Yap didn't actually move these rai stones around or exchange them as we do with coins, because rai stones can be quite massive. The largest is about four tons and 12 feet across. So, the Yap just kept track of who owned each stone. There's a story about sailors who were transporting a stone across the ocean when they encountered trouble, and the stone fell in.

You've been accused of a crime you did not commit. It’s nearly impossible to prove your innocence. If you insist you’re innocent anyway, you’ll likely be found guilty and executed. But if you confess, apologize, and implicate others for good measure, you’ll go free. Do you give a false confession—or risk a public hanging? This was the choice facing those accused of witchcraft in the village of Salem, Massachusetts, between February 1692 and May 1693. They were victims of paranoia about the supernatural, misdirected religious fervor, and a justice system that valued repentance over truth. Salem was settled in 1626 by Puritans, a group of English Protestants. Life was strict and isolated for the people of Salem. Battles with their Native American neighbors and groups of French settlers were commonplace.

Currently, hundreds of thousands await critical organs like kidneys, hearts, and livers on transplant lists, hoping for lifesaving donations. Unfortunately, donor organs are far too scarce to meet this demand. What if, instead of waiting, we could create brand-new, customized organs from scratch? This is the idea behind bioprinting, an innovative branch of regenerative medicine under development. While the ability to print complex organs remains out of reach, simpler tissues such as blood vessels and tubes for nutrient and waste exchange are already within our grasp. Bioprinting is akin to 3D printing, a method that layers material to construct a three-dimensional object one slice at a time.

Good afternoon. I'm proud to be here at TEDxKrakow. I'll try to discuss a phenomenon that is transforming the world: people power. I'll begin with an anecdote, or for those who love Monty Python, a Monty Python-like sketch. Here it is: It is December 15, 2010. Someone offers you a bet: you will look into a crystal ball, seeing an accurate future, and you must share it with the world. Okay, curiosity killed the cat, so you accept the bet and peer into the crystal ball. One hour later, you're in a building of national TV, on a top show, recounting the story.

We begin in 1964. Bob Dylan, 23 years old, sees his career reaching its pinnacle. He's named the voice of a generation and creates classic songs at an astounding rate. However, a small group of dissenters claims Dylan is stealing songs. Fast forward to 2004. Brian Burton, aka Danger Mouse, takes the Beatles' "White Album" and combines it with Jay-Z's "The Black Album" to create "The Grey Album." "The Grey Album" quickly becomes an online sensation, prompting the Beatles' record company to send countless cease-and-desist letters for "unfair competition and dilution of our valuable property." Now, "The Grey Album" is a remix.

That's quite an obvious statement up there. I began with that thought around 12 years ago, focusing on developing countries, but you all are representing every corner of the world. If you consider a map of your own country, you'll realize that for every nation on Earth, you could mark areas as "these are places where good teachers won't go." Moreover, those are often the places from which trouble emerges. So we have an ironic problem — good teachers avoid the very areas where they're needed the most. I started in 1999 to tackle this issue with an experiment, which was a straightforward venture in New Delhi.

Currently, most refugees reside in cities rather than refugee camps, representing over 60 percent of the global refugee population. With the majority living in urban areas, there is a strong need for a paradigm shift and innovative thinking. Rather than wasting money on building walls, it would be better to invest in programs that empower refugees to help themselves. We always have to leave behind all our possessions but not our skills and knowledge. If allowed to lead productive lives, refugees can support themselves and contribute to the development of their host country. I was born in the city of Bukavu, South Kivu, in the Democratic Republic of Congo. I am the fifth-born in a family of 12 children.

I have two questions for you. One: whose shoulders do you stand on? And two: what do you stand for? These are two questions that I always begin my poetry workshops with because, at times, poetry can seem like a dead art form for old white men who appear to have been born to be old, like, you know, Benjamin Button or something. I ask my students these two questions, then I share my answers in these three sentences: I am the daughter of Black writers, who are descended from freedom fighters who broke their chains and changed the world. They call me. These are words I repeat as a mantra before every single poetry performance. In fact, I was doing it in the corner over there, making faces.

(Laughter) I was a self-employed living statue called the Eight-Foot Bride, and I love telling people I did this for a job, because everyone always wants to know, who are these performers in real life. And if they didn't take the flower, I added a gesture of sadness and longing — as they walked away.

On October 4, 1957, the world watched in awe and fear as the Soviet Union launched Sputnik, the first man-made satellite, into space. This small metal sphere, less than two feet in diameter, initiated a space race between the U.S. and U.S.S.R. that would last for eighteen years and alter the world as we know it. However, Sputnik was not the first piece of human technology to reach space. That distinction belongs to the V-2 rocket used by Germany in missile attacks against Allied cities as a last-ditch effort in the final years of World War II. Although it wasn't very effective, at the end of the war, both the U.S. and U.S.S.R. captured the technology and the scientists who developed it and began using them for their own projects.

I am a cultural omnivore, one whose daily commute is made possible by attachment to an iPod—an iPod that contains Wagner and Mozart, pop diva Christina Aguilera, country singer Josh Turner, artist Kirk Franklin, concerti, symphonies, and more. I'm a voracious reader, one who delves into Ian McEwan down to Stephanie Meyer. I have read the Twilight tetralogy. I live for my home theater, where I devour DVDs, video on demand, and a lot of television. For me, "Law & Order: SVU," Tina Fey and "30 Rock," and "Judge Judy"—"the people are real, the cases are real, the rulings are final.

[Citizens of the world] [we face a global crisis of unprecedented scale] [please stand by for a message from ...] [the Secretary-General of the United Nations António Guterres] The climate emergency is the defining crisis of our time. We are in a race against time, and we are losing. There is a growing tide of impatience, especially among young people, with global inaction. We need more ambition from all: governments, cities, businesses, investors, and people everywhere. So I'm pleased you are launching TED Countdown. Your influence and ideas can help accelerate momentum for a carbon-neutral world by 2050. That is the only way to avert the worst impacts of global heating. We have the tools, the science, and the resources. Let us now step into this race with political will and energy.

Menstruation, a simple word describing a natural biological process, has been weighed down by centuries of stigma, transformed into something most of us only speak about in whispers. But why? As I speak to you right now, over 800 million women around the world are having a period. None of us would exist without it, yet it remains an "embarrassing" subject to broach. From my experience and that of the women around me, I can tell you it's exhausting. It's exhausting to carefully take out a brown paper bag hiding a pad, stuff it into your pocket in the middle of a class, and rush to the washroom as discreetly as possible. It's exhausting to sit through lessons and meetings, pretending to be absolutely normal while internally crying out from intense period cramps.

The world's largest and most devastating environmental and industrial project is situated in the heart of the largest and most intact forest in the world, Canada's boreal forest. It stretches across northern Canada, and in Labrador, it's home to the largest remaining wild caribou herd: the George River caribou herd, numbering approximately 400,000 animals. Unfortunately, when I was there, I couldn't find one of them, but the antlers are proof. Across the boreal, we're blessed with an incredible abundance of wetlands. Wetlands, globally, are among the most endangered ecosystems. They're absolutely critical, cleaning air and water, sequestering large amounts of greenhouse gases, and hosting a huge diversity of species.

Before the world of humans began, there was the world of the gods, filled with fields, plains, and gardens. Four brothers wandered this celestial realm. They had no family other than each other—they didn’t even know their parents. One of the brothers, Deminan, looked different from the others. His skin was covered in painful scabs, and he wondered why he alone was marked with this affliction. One day, while the supreme spirit Yaya was out in his gardens, Deminan and his brothers snuck into Yaya’s house. After feasting and exploring, they spotted a giant gourd hanging in the corner, but as they tried to look inside, they dropped it.

Seven years ago, I graduated from Berkeley with a dual degree in molecular and cell biology and linguistics. I attended a career fair on campus, where I obtained an interview with a startup called Theranos. At the time, there was limited information about the company, but what was available was impressive. Essentially, the company was developing a medical device that allowed you to run your entire blood panel with just a finger-stick. This innovation eliminated the need for a large needle in the arm for blood tests. This was intriguing not only because it was less painful, but it also had the potential to advance predictive diagnostics.

My journey to becoming a polar specialist, photographing and specializing in the polar regions, began when I was four years old. My family moved from southern Canada to northern Baffin Island, near Greenland. There, we lived with the Inuit in a tiny community of 200 people, where we were one of three non-Inuit families. In this community, we didn't have a television, computers, or radio. We didn't even have a telephone. All of my time was spent outside with the Inuit. The snow and ice were my sandbox, and the Inuit were my teachers. That's where I became truly obsessed with the polar realm.

We're seen as the organization that is the repository for failed social policy. I can't define who comes to us or how long they will stay. We get the people for whom nothing else has worked, those who have fallen through all other social safety nets. They can't manage them, so we must. That's our job: manage them, control them. Over the years, as a prison system, as a nation, and as a society, we've become very proficient at that, but it shouldn't make you happy. Today we incarcerate more people per capita than any other country in the world. We have more black men in prison today than were under slavery in 1850.

I'd like to take you on the epic quest of the Rosetta spacecraft. Escorting and landing the probe on a comet has been my passion for the past two years. To do that, I need to explain something about the origin of the solar system. Four and a half billion years ago, there was a cloud of gas and dust. In the center of this cloud, our sun formed and ignited. Along with that, what we now know as planets, comets, and asteroids formed. According to theory, when the Earth had cooled down after its formation, comets massively impacted the planet, delivering water. They probably also brought complex organic material, which may have bootstrapped the emergence of life.

In 1903, the President of the United States took a three-day camping trip in California’s Yosemite Valley. President Theodore Roosevelt slept among a grove of towering sequoia trees, camped during a snowstorm, and spent hours conversing around the campfire with his host and guide, conservationist John Muir. Roosevelt famously adored the outdoors, but Muir had invited him for purposes beyond camping: Yosemite was in peril. Though Yosemite became protected land in 1864, the valley faced the threat of overdevelopment in 1903. It was at the center of a decades-old struggle to reserve land for both preservation and public use—two goals easier stated than accomplished. The battle over Yosemite began with the 1849 Gold Rush, when miners surged west, seeking gold in the Sierra Nevada foothills.

Hello. This is my first trip, the first time in my life I'm outside the walls of Gaza. I'm so happy to be here. (applause) My ambition was always to be a pilot, to fly a plane, to feel free in the sky, to touch the sky. But that didn't happen. Simply, I live in Gaza; there is no airport. All borders are closed on every side. We live in one of the biggest prisons in the world. The only thing I can do is just look up at the sky. On some days, we are lucky if we have electricity for four or five hours. When it's cold, we make a fire in front or on the roof of our homes.

I'm sorry, I cannot show you my face, because if I do, the bad guys will come for me. My journey started 14 years ago. I was a young reporter who had just graduated from college when I got a scoop. It was a simple story: police officers were taking bribes from street vendors. As a young reporter, I wanted to approach it differently so it would have the maximum impact, since everyone knew it was happening, yet nothing was preventing it from continuing. So, I decided to go undercover and pose as a vendor. By doing this, I was able to gather hard evidence. The impact was great; it was fantastic. This was what many call immersive journalism or undercover journalism.

One simple vitamin can reduce your risk of heart disease. Eating chocolate reduces stress in students. A new drug prolongs the lives of patients with a rare disease. Health headlines like these are published every day, sometimes making opposing claims. There can be a disconnect between broad, attention-grabbing headlines and the often specific, incremental results of the medical research they cover. How can you avoid being misled by sensational headlines? The best way to assess a headline’s credibility is to look at the original research it reports on. We’ve come up with a hypothetical research scenario for each of these headlines. Keep watching for the explanation of the first example; then pause at the headline to answer the question. These are simplified scenarios.

When I was 14, my family was in the process of adopting my little brothers from Ethiopia. One day, my mom asked, "Which day should we choose for their birthday?" I thought, "The day they were born, obviously?" It seemed like a ridiculous question. Then my mom explained, "Well, Kristen, neither of your little brothers has a birth certificate, so how do you suggest we find out when that was?" My mind was blown. Now, 20 years later, I'm still working on it. Instead of solving my brothers' missing birth certificates, I aim to address this issue globally. So what do birth certificates have to do with international development?

Imagine if you could connect your brain to a machine that would provide ultimate pleasure for the rest of your life. If given the choice to opt for such an existence, would you? That's the question philosopher Robert Nozick posed through a thought experiment he called the experience machine. The experiment invites us to consider a world where scientists have developed a machine that simulates real life while guaranteeing experiences of only pleasure, never pain. The catch? You must permanently leave reality behind, but you'll scarcely notice the difference. Your experiences will be indistinguishable from reality. Life's natural ups and downs will be replaced with an endless series of highs. Sounds great, right?

I would like to share the most embarrassing incident from my years as a palliative care physician. This occurred a couple of years ago. I was consulted to see a woman in her 70s—a retired English professor with pancreatic cancer. She was experiencing pain, nausea, and vomiting. We discussed these symptoms during my visit, and she inquired whether medical marijuana might help her. I reflected on my medical school education regarding medical marijuana, which took no time because I had learned absolutely nothing.

For the past 24 years, I have been a firefighter in Huntington, West Virginia. As firefighters, my team and I are tasked with saving lives and property from disasters such as car accidents, house fires, and life-threatening medical emergencies. I am a woman leading a department in a male-dominated profession. Ten years ago, I decided to expand my medical knowledge by obtaining a nursing degree. This was because it became apparent that the next major threat facing not only my city but others nationwide was not the one-time disaster, where you can rush in like the cavalry, extinguish the fire, and leave, feeling like you have truly made a difference, with everything now under control.

Where does all the carbon we release go? Carbon cycles naturally, present in all living things: in the soil, oceans, atmosphere, and rocks deep underground. When plants and living things die, much of their stored carbon returns to the atmosphere until new plants grow and reabsorb it. Over millions of years, some of the carbon stored in ancient trees and sea life becomes rock, and some becomes fossil fuels: coal, oil, and natural gas. Natural events like volcanic eruptions release some of the carbon trapped in rock. Human activities, like burning fossil fuels, also release some of that prehistoric carbon. Today, humans release around 60 times more carbon than all the volcanoes on the planet each year.

Even nature's most unsavory creatures harbor vital secrets, yet who would welcome a swarm of cockroaches approaching them? One of the significant distinctions between natural and human technologies is robustness. Robust systems remain stable in challenging and unfamiliar environments. Amazingly, cockroaches can self-stabilize while traversing rough terrain. When equipped with a jet pack or subjected to disturbances like earthquakes, their remarkably adapted legs enable them to self-stabilize without relying on any brainpower. They navigate complex terrains like grass effortlessly without destabilization. We observed a new behavior where, due to their shape, they automatically roll to their side to traverse this artificial test patch of grass. Robust systems are capable of performing multiple tasks using the same structure. Here's the new behavior we've observed.

These are grim economic times, fellow Tedsters, grim economic times indeed. Comparable, in its own very peculiar way, to the achievements of Microsoft or Google. It's an industry that has weathered the current recession with equanimity. I refer to organized crime. Now organized crime has been around for a very long time, I hear you say, and these would be wise words indeed. But in the last two decades, it has experienced unprecedented expansion, now accounting for roughly 15 percent of the world's GDP. I like to call it the global shadow economy, or McMafia, for short. So what triggered this extraordinary growth in cross-border crime?

If you ask people which aspect of psychology they find difficult, and you mention "thinking and emotions," most will respond, "Emotions are incredibly complex. I have no idea how they work. But thinking is quite straightforward: it’s just some kind of logical reasoning." However, that’s not the challenging part. Here's a list of issues that arise.
